question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Name recognition: While Donald Trump Jr. has a high profile due to his father's presidency, he has never held elected office himself, which could be a significant disadvantage. 3. Political experience: Compared to other potential candidates, Donald Trump Jr. lacks direct political experience, which voters and party officials often consider important for a presidential nominee. 4. Family dynamics: It's unlikely that both Donald Trump Sr. and Jr. would run in the same election cycle, as this could split their base of support. If Trump Sr. remains in the race, it's highly improbable that Jr. would enter. 5. Party preferences: The Republican Party typically favors candidates with governmental experience or a strong political track record, which Donald Trump Jr. lacks. 6. Time until convention: While there's still time until the 2024 Republican National Convention, Donald Trump Jr. has not shown any signs of preparing for a presidential run. 7. Current focus: Donald Trump Jr. seems more focused on supporting his father's political endeavors and engaging in political commentary rather than pursuing his own candidacy. 8. Polling data: Current polls do not show significant support for Donald Trump Jr. as a potential nominee compared to other candidates. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could change the political landscape, based on the current situation, the probability is very low.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Asa Hutchinson becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, the Republican field for 2024 is dominated by high-profile candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley. Asa Hutchinson is considered a long-shot candidate with significantly less name recognition and support. 2. Polling data: In most national polls, Hutchinson is consistently polling at 1% or less among Republican primary voters. This indicates a very low level of support compared to frontrunners. 3. Fundraising: Hutchinson's campaign has struggled to raise significant funds compared to other candidates, which limits his ability to compete effectively on a national scale. 4. Political positioning: Hutchinson has positioned himself as an anti-Trump Republican, which may appeal to some moderate Republicans but alienates a large portion of the party's base that still strongly supports Trump. 5. Experience: While Hutchinson has experience as a former governor of Arkansas and federal official, his national profile is relatively low compared to other candidates. 6. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a candidate polling so low and with such limited resources to surge and win a major party nomination. 7. Time until convention: While there is still time until the Republican National Convention in 2024, Hutchinson would need an extraordinary and unprecedented turnaround to become a serious contender. 8. Party dynamics: The Republican Party's current direction seems to favor candidates who align more closely with Trump's policies and style, which Hutchinson has explicitly rejected. Given these factors, the probability of Asa Hutchinson becoming the Republican nominee is extremely low. While not impossible, it would require a series of highly unlikely events and a dramatic shift in the political landscape.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates or combinations will resolve as **No**. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The probability of both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson being the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is extremely low for several reasons: 1. Traditionally, the Republican Party nominates a single candidate for President, not two. The question seems to imply a scenario where both would be nominees, which is highly unusual and unprecedented. 2. Donald Trump Jr. has not officially announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election. While he is a prominent figure in Republican circles due to his father's presidency, he has not shown clear intentions to run. 3. Asa Hutchinson, the former Governor of Arkansas, has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican nomination. However, he is considered a long-shot candidate with low polling numbers and limited national recognition. 4. The Republican field for 2024 is expected to be competitive, with more prominent figures like Donald Trump Sr., Ron DeSantis, and others either already running or likely to run. These candidates have much higher name recognition and support within the party. 5. The scenario where both Trump Jr. and Hutchinson would be chosen as nominees would require a dramatic change in the Republican Party's nomination process, which is highly unlikely. 6. Even if the party were to choose a ticket with two nominees, it's improbable they would select these two specific individuals together, as they represent different factions within the party and have no notable history of working together. Given these factors, the probability of this specific scenario occurring is virtually zero. While not impossible in theory, it would require such a radical departure from established political norms and current political realities that it's extremely implausible.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extremely low approval ratings. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Current intentions: As of now (July 2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He officially launched his campaign in April 2023. 3. Age and health concerns: Biden is currently 80 years old and would be 82 at the start of a second term. While his health appears stable, concerns about his age and stamina persist. 4. Approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, hovering around 40-45% in recent months. However, they're not catastrophically low to the point where the party would force him out. 5. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden's re-election bid. There's no significant push within the party for an alternative candidate. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's highly unlikely for a sitting president to drop out so late in the process. 7. Potential successors: There's no clear alternative candidate who has been positioning themselves to take over if Biden steps aside. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination, especially so late in the process. The only scenario where this might happen would be a sudden, severe health issue, which is unpredictable but relatively unlikely.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

The question asks about changes over the next week, which is a very short period in political terms. 3. Volatility of polling: Political polls and forecasts can be volatile, but significant changes typically require major events or developments. 4. Kamala Harris's position: As the current Vice President, Harris is a prominent figure in the Democratic Party. However, she's not currently the presumptive nominee for the 2024 election. 5. Political landscape: Without specific information about upcoming events or developments that could significantly impact Harris's standing, it's unlikely to see a major shift in such a short timeframe. 6. Nate Silver's model: Silver's models are known for their robustness and resistance to short-term fluctuations, preferring to react to sustained trends or significant events. 7. Margin for increase: With the current probability at 46.6%, there's limited room for a meaningful increase in just one week, especially given the model's likely stability. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that Harris's odds would increase significantly in just one week. While small fluctuations are possible, a notable increase that would resolve this question as YES appears improbable. The model would likely require more substantial changes in the political landscape or a series of positive developments for Harris to show a meaningful increase.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (2) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This resolves Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

This resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine them. 1. Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic nomination: As of now (July 2024), Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. It's extremely rare for a sitting president to decline their party's nomination for a second term, especially this late in the election cycle. Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. While there have been concerns about his age and approval ratings, there's no strong indication that he plans to step aside. The deadline (July 15, 2024) is very close, leaving little time for such a major decision to be made and announced. Therefore, this part is highly unlikely. 2. However, even if Biden did make such an announcement, there's no guarantee that Harris would immediately become the frontrunner. Other candidates might enter the race, and Harris's popularity and electability are not assured. Additionally, the timeframe for this increase (over the next week) is very short, which makes it even less likely for a significant change to occur and be reflected in the model. For both parts to occur, we would need an extremely unlikely event (Biden stepping down) followed by a specific reaction in the polling models. The combination of these two low-probability events makes the overall probability very low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but it's rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. Colorado and Minnesota have seen significant legal battles on this issue. 3. State-level decisions: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently. Some states might be more inclined to remove Trump from the ballot than others. 4. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal challenges to be filed, heard, and potentially appealed. 5. Political climate: The issue is highly politicized, which could influence decision-making processes in different states. 6. Supreme Court involvement: Given the high-profile nature of this issue, it's likely that any state-level decision to remove Trump from the ballot would be appealed to the Supreme Court. The Court's decision would likely set a precedent for all states. 7. Trump's actions and statements: His involvement in the January 6th events and subsequent statements could be used as evidence in these cases. 8. Constitutional interpretation: There's debate among legal scholars about whether Section 3 of the 14th Amendment can be applied without additional legislation. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that at least one state might remove or block Trump from the primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. However, it's far from certain. The legal and political hurdles are substantial, and there's a good chance that even if a state does make such a decision, it could be overturned by higher courts before the resolution date.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health status: As of July 2024, Joe Biden is 81 years old and generally in good health for his age. He undergoes regular medical check-ups, and there have been no recent reports of serious health concerns. 2. Life expectancy: The average life expectancy for an American male is around 76 years. Biden has already surpassed this, but as a high-ranking official with access to excellent healthcare, his life expectancy is likely higher than average. 3. Short timeframe: The question asks about a very specific and short timeframe - approximately 3 weeks from the creation date to the resolution date. The probability of any specific individual dying within such a short period is generally low, barring any known severe health issues or external threats. 4. Security measures: As the President of the United States, Biden is under constant protection by the Secret Service, which significantly reduces the risk of death by external causes such as accidents or attacks. 5. Scheduled activities: Unless there are any high-risk activities planned for Biden during this period (which is unlikely given his position), his day-to-day activities are generally low-risk. 6. No known imminent threats: There are no publicly known imminent threats to Biden's life as of the question's creation date. Given these factors, the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, is very low. While it's impossible to predict with absolute certainty, and unexpected events can always occur, the combination of his current health status, the short timeframe, and the security measures in place make it highly unlikely.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and age: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While he has maintained relatively good health, his advanced age does increase the risk of health issues. 2. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and no President has resigned since Richard Nixon in 1974. This suggests a low probability of either event occurring. 3. Political stability: As of now, there are no major political crises or scandals that would likely lead to Biden's resignation. 4. Time frame: The question only asks about a period of approximately one month (from the creation date to the end of July 2024). This short timeframe reduces the likelihood of unexpected events occurring. 5. 2024 Election: While the 2024 presidential election will be approaching, it won't take place until November, well after the period in question. 6. 25th Amendment clause: The question specifically states that temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not count as ceasing to be President, which eliminates one potential way Biden might briefly not be serving as President. 7. Biden's commitment: Biden has shown no indications of wanting to step down from the presidency and has expressed interest in running for re-election in 2024. Given these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is quite high. The main risk factors are his age and the possibility of unexpected health issues, but these are mitigated by the short time frame in question and his current good health.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). Resolves NO otherwise. Note: Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not impact the resolution as long as he remains President.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Joe Biden's current health and age: As of July 2024, Joe Biden would be 81 years old. While he has had some health issues in the past, there have been no recent reports of severe health concerns that would suggest an imminent risk of death. 2. Likelihood of sudden death: For any individual, especially at an advanced age, there's always a possibility of sudden death due to various factors like heart attack, stroke, or accident. However, as the President, Biden receives excellent medical care and constant monitoring, which reduces this risk. 3. Time frame: The question specifies a very short time frame - from July 5, 2024 (creation date) to July 26, 2024 (market close on Friday). This is only about three weeks, which is an extremely short period for such a significant event to occur. 4. Continuation as President after death: The second part of the condition, that Biden remains President through the end of July 2024 even after death, is highly improbable. In the event of a President's death, the Vice President immediately assumes the role of President as per the U.S. Constitution. 5. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and none have remained 'President' after death. Given these factors, the probability of this scenario occurring is extremely low. The combination of Biden dying within this short timeframe AND somehow remaining President after death makes this scenario highly implausible.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

Fundraising and support: Pence would need to build a strong fundraising network and gather support from key Republican figures to be competitive. Political climate: The Republican party has been shifting towards a more populist, Trump-aligned stance, which may not favor Pence's more traditional conservative approach. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Mike Pence will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not impossible, as political landscapes can shift rapidly, the current evidence suggests that Pence faces significant obstacles in securing the nomination.

The most likely outcome is that either Donald Trump or another single candidate will secure the nomination.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Indian National Congress (INC) forming the government after the next Indian general election in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been in power since 2014 and won a significant majority in the 2019 elections. The INC, the main opposition party, has struggled to regain its former prominence. 2. Recent electoral performance: The INC has faced significant losses in recent state elections and has been unable to form strong coalitions to challenge the BJP effectively. 3. Leadership issues: The INC has been grappling with internal leadership challenges, with questions about the effectiveness of the Gandhi family's leadership and the lack of a clear alternative. 4. BJP's strengths: The BJP has a strong organizational structure, significant financial resources, and a charismatic leader in Narendra Modi, who still maintains considerable popularity. 5. Anti-incumbency factor: While this could potentially work against the BJP, the opposition, including the INC, has not been able to capitalize on it effectively so far. 6. Regional parties: The rise of strong regional parties has further fragmented the opposition vote, making it more challenging for the INC to form a cohesive alliance. 7. Time until elections: There is still about a year until the expected election date, which could allow for some shifts in the political landscape. However, major changes seem unlikely given the current scenario. 8. Historical trends: While the INC has formed governments in the past, its influence has been declining over the past decade. Given these factors, it appears unlikely that the INC will be able to form the government after the 2024 general election. While political situations can be unpredictable, the current evidence suggests that the INC faces significant challenges in overcoming the BJP's dominance and uniting a fragmented opposition.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both the Indian National Congress (INC) and Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) forming the government after the 2024 Indian general election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical precedent: In India's political history, there has never been a situation where both the INC and BJP have shared power in a coalition government at the national level. Current political landscape: The BJP, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has been in power since 2014 and won a significant majority in the 2019 elections. Coalition politics: While coalition governments are common in India, they typically involve one major national party (either BJP or INC) aligning with regional parties, not with each other. 4. Public perception: Such an alliance would likely be seen as a betrayal of their respective voter bases, potentially causing significant political backlash. 6. Electoral system: India follows a first-past-the-post system, which typically results in one party or pre-election alliance gaining a majority, rather than necessitating a post-election coalition between major rivals. 7. Recent trends: The BJP has been gaining strength in recent years, while the INC has been losing ground. This makes it even less likely for the BJP to need or want to form a government with the INC. 8. Leadership: Current leaders of both parties (Narendra Modi for BJP and Rahul Gandhi for INC) have shown no inclination towards working together in a coalition. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Existing opposition: The context already mentions that "dozens" of House Democrats are organizing to speak out against the early nomination plan. This suggests there is significant opposition within the party. 2. Time frame: The market closes on July 21st, which gives about a week for the letter to be finalized and signed. This is a relatively short time, but not impossibly so for organizing such an effort. 3. Number of signatures required: The threshold of 20 signatures is relatively low, considering there are currently 213 Democratic Representatives in the House and 48 Democratic Senators (plus 3 Independents who caucus with Democrats). 4. Motivation: The opposition seems to stem from concerns about stifling debate and achieving forced unity, which could be important issues for many Democratic lawmakers. 5. Political climate: With the 2024 election approaching and the mentioned assassination attempt on Trump, there's likely to be heightened political tension and scrutiny on party decisions. 6. Precedent: Democrats have shown willingness to publicly disagree with party leadership in the past, especially on procedural matters. 7. Rep. Huffman's involvement: While he declined to confirm the letter's existence, his willingness to speak about the opposition suggests the effort is serious. 8. Potential backlash: Some lawmakers might be hesitant to sign due to fear of party repercussions or appearing disloyal to Biden. Given these factors, it seems quite likely that a letter will be produced and signed by at least 20 Democratic lawmakers. The existing organization, the relatively low threshold of signatures needed, and the short but manageable timeframe all point towards a high probability of success. However, there's still some uncertainty due to potential hesitation from lawmakers and the possibility of the effort falling short in the given time.

question.title: Will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Time frame: The resolution date is July 20, 2024, which is only about 5 days from the creation date of July 15, 2024. This is a very short time frame for such a significant political shift to occur. 2. Current political climate: As of July 2024, there have been no major scandals or controversies surrounding President Biden that would warrant such a drastic action from Democratic Senators. 3. Party unity: Democrats typically try to maintain a united front, especially in an election year. Calling for the incumbent president to drop out would be extremely divisive and potentially damaging to the party's chances in the upcoming election. 4. Biden's status: While there have been concerns about Biden's age and occasional gaffes, he remains the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. The party has generally rallied behind him. 5. Precedent: It is extremely rare for senators from the same party to call for a sitting president to drop out of a re-election campaign, especially in such large numbers (10 or more). 6. Alternative candidates: There is no clear alternative candidate who has widespread support within the Democratic party that could justify such a dramatic move. 7. Electoral consequences: Such a move could be seen as handing the election to the Republican candidate, which Democratic senators would be very reluctant to do. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that 10 or more Democratic Senators would call for Biden to drop out in such a short time frame. The probability of this occurring is very low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early AND will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
This question resolves to YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before the end of Sunday, July 21st. This includes multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures.

2. 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, as confirmed by the New York Times source.

If both conditions are met, the question resolves to YES. If either or both conditions are not met, the question resolves to NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both conditions separately and then evaluate the likelihood of both occurring together. 1. 20+ House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing early nomination of Biden: This condition seems unlikely for several reasons: a) There's currently no widespread public dissent among Democrats regarding Biden's nomination. b) Party unity is typically prioritized, especially close to elections. c) The timeframe is very short (less than a week from the question's creation date). d) 20 is a significant number of lawmakers to openly oppose the party's presumptive nominee. 2. 10+ Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out before July 20: This condition seems even more unlikely: a) There have been no recent indications of Democratic Senators wanting Biden to drop out. b) The deadline is even shorter (5 days from the question's creation date). c) 10 Senators represent a substantial portion of the Democratic Senate caucus. d) Such a move would be extremely disruptive to the party's election strategy. For both conditions to be met, there would need to be a sudden, major event or revelation that dramatically changes the political landscape. While not impossible, this seems highly improbable given the current political climate and the extremely short timeframe. Moreover, the conjunction of two unlikely events makes the overall probability even lower. Even if we assume a generous 10% chance for each condition (which seems high given the circumstances), the probability of both occurring would be 0.1 * 0.1 = 0.01 or 1%. Given these factors, I would assess the probability of both conditions being met as extremely low.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the USA winning more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: The USA has consistently been a top performer at the Olympics. In recent Summer Olympics, they have typically won more Gold medals than Silver: - Tokyo 2020 (2021): 39 Gold, 41 Silver - Rio 2016: 46 Gold, 37 Silver - London 2012: 46 Gold, 29 Silver - Beijing 2008: 36 Gold, 38 Silver 2. Strength of the US team: The USA has strong programs in swimming, athletics, gymnastics, and many other sports, which contribute significantly to their Gold medal count. 3. Competition from other countries: While the USA is strong, other nations like China, ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), and Japan have been improving their performances, which could impact the USA's medal distribution. 4. Home advantage: The USA won't have a home advantage in Paris, which could slightly decrease their overall performance compared to a home Olympics. 5. Variability in performance: Olympic results can be unpredictable, with small margins often separating Gold from Silver. 6. COVID-19 impact: The pandemic's long-term effects on athlete training and development could influence performance, though this impact should be less significant by 2024. Looking at the recent history, the USA has won more Gold than Silver medals in three out of the last four Summer Olympics. The exception was Tokyo 2020, where they won slightly more Silver than Gold, possibly due to pandemic-related disruptions and the rise of other nations' competitiveness. Given the USA's consistent strong performance and their tendency to win more Gold than Silver, I believe it's more likely than not that they will achieve this in Paris 2024. However, the increasing competitiveness of other nations and the unpredictability of Olympic performances introduce some uncertainty.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the USA topping the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: The USA has consistently been a top performer in the Summer Olympics. They topped the medal table in the last three Summer Olympics (2016 Rio, 2012 London, and 2021 Tokyo). 2. Strength of the US team: The USA has a strong sports infrastructure, excellent training facilities, and a large pool of talented athletes across various disciplines. 3. Competition: China is typically the USA's main rival for the top spot. Other strong contenders include ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), Great Britain, and Japan. 4. Home advantage: Unlike in Tokyo 2020 (held in 2021), where Japan had a home advantage, there's no clear home advantage for any major medal-winning country in Paris 2024. 5. Consistency: The USA's performance has been relatively consistent across recent Olympics, showing their ability to maintain their competitive edge. 6. Investment in sports: The USA continues to invest heavily in Olympic sports, which helps maintain their competitive advantage. 7. Potential challenges: Emerging sports powers, changes in Olympic programs, or unexpected performances from other countries could pose challenges. 8. COVID-19 impact: While the pandemic disrupted training for all countries, its long-term effects on athletic performance are still uncertain. Given these factors, the USA has a strong chance of topping the medal table again. Their consistent performance, strong sports infrastructure, and lack of home advantage for major competitors work in their favor. However, strong competition from countries like China and the potential for surprises in Olympic performances mean it's not a certainty.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals and also top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, based on the medal table that orders by number of Gold Medals, then Silver, then Bronze. The question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves negatively if either condition (a) or (b) is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider historical Olympic performance, current trends in US athletics, and potential competition from other countries. 1. Historical performance: The United States has consistently been a top performer at the Summer Olympics. In recent Games, they have often topped the medal table: - 2020 Tokyo: 1st (39 gold, 41 silver) - 2016 Rio: 1st (46 gold, 37 silver) - 2012 London: 1st (46 gold, 29 silver) 2. Gold vs. Silver medals: While the US typically wins more gold than silver medals, this isn't always the case (as seen in Tokyo 2020). The margin is often close. 3. Competition: China is the main rival for the top spot. Other strong contenders include ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), Great Britain, and Japan. 4. US athletic development: The US has strong programs in swimming, track and field, and team sports, which contribute significantly to their medal count. 5. Home advantage: France may perform better than usual as the host nation, potentially affecting the medal distribution. 6. Emerging sports: New Olympic sports (like skateboarding and sport climbing) could slightly alter traditional medal distributions. 7. Post-pandemic effects: The shorter gap between Tokyo 2020 and Paris 2024 might benefit athletes who performed well in Tokyo, including many Americans. Given these factors, the US has a strong chance of topping the medal table. However, winning more gold than silver medals is less certain. The US needs to meet both conditions for this question to resolve as 'Yes.' While the US is favored to top the medal table, the gold-to-silver ratio is more unpredictable. There's a significant chance they could win more silver than gold, or an equal number, which would result in a 'No' resolution. Considering all factors, I estimate there's about a 60% chance of both conditions being met.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Family dynamics: It's highly unlikely that both Donald Trump Sr. and Jr. would run in the same election cycle, as this would split their base and potentially harm the family's political brand. 3. Political experience: Donald Trump Jr. has never held elected office, which would be a significant disadvantage in a presidential primary. Most successful nominees have experience as governors, senators, or high-ranking officials. 4. Name recognition: While Trump Jr. has high name recognition due to his father's presidency, this could be a double-edged sword, as he may be seen as riding on his father's coattails rather than having his own political identity. 5. Party dynamics: The Republican Party is currently still very much aligned with Donald Trump Sr. It's unlikely they would pivot to his son without a significant change in circumstances. 6. Time until convention: There is still considerable time until the 2024 Republican National Convention. While this allows for potential changes in the political landscape, it also means that current frontrunners have time to solidify their positions. 7. Lack of campaign infrastructure: As of now, there's no indication that Trump Jr. has been building the necessary campaign infrastructure or donor network required for a presidential run. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that Donald Trump Jr. would become the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could change the political landscape, the current situation suggests a very low likelihood of this outcome.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Donald Trump be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Donald Trump are selected by the Republican National Convention as nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This scenario requires that both individuals are officially nominated by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Constitutional limitations: The 12th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution prohibits electors from voting for president and vice president from the same state. Since both Donald Trump and Donald Trump Jr. are from the same state (New York), this would create a significant legal obstacle. 2. Precedent: There has never been a father-son ticket for a major party nomination in U.S. presidential history. This lack of precedent makes such a scenario highly unlikely. 3. Republican Party dynamics: While Donald Trump maintains significant influence within the Republican Party, there is also a growing faction seeking to move beyond the Trump era. Nominating both Trumps would likely be seen as excessive and potentially alienating to moderate voters. 4. Donald Trump Jr.'s political experience: While he has been involved in his father's campaigns and administration, Donald Trump Jr. has never held elected office. This lack of direct political experience makes him an unlikely choice for a vice-presidential nominee. 5. Other potential candidates: There are numerous other experienced Republican politicians who would likely be considered for the vice-presidential nomination before Donald Trump Jr., including current governors, senators, and former administration officials. 6. Public perception: A father-son ticket might be perceived negatively by many voters as an attempt to establish a political dynasty, which could be unpopular even among some Trump supporters. 7. Legal challenges: Donald Trump is currently facing various legal issues, which could potentially impact his ability to run or his appeal as a candidate. This uncertainty makes the scenario of both Trumps being nominated even less likely. Given these factors, it is extremely improbable that both Donald Trump and Donald Trump Jr. would be nominated as the Republican candidates for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not entirely impossible, the combination of legal, political, and practical obstacles makes this scenario highly unlikely.

question.title: Will at least 5 countries win their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Games?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of at least 5 countries winning their first Olympic medal at the 2024 Paris Games, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical precedent: In recent Olympics, it's been relatively common for a few countries to win their first medals. For example: - Tokyo 2020: 3 countries (Burkina Faso, San Marino, Turkmenistan) - Rio 2016: 3 countries (Fiji, Jordan, Kosovo) - London 2012: 5 countries (Cyprus, Grenada, Guatemala, Montenegro, South Sudan) 2. Number of participating countries: The Olympics typically feature around 200 nations. As of 2021, there were still about 72 countries that had never won an Olympic medal. 3. Emerging sports: The 2024 Paris Olympics will include new sports like breaking (breakdancing), which could provide opportunities for countries with strengths in these areas to win their first medals. 4. Development of sports programs: Many countries have been investing in their Olympic programs, increasing the chances of breakthrough performances. 5. Geopolitical changes: New countries or recently recognized nations may participate for the first time or with renewed focus. 6. Expanded opportunities: The IOC has been working to increase participation and representation from a wider range of countries, which could lead to more first-time medalists. 7. Random chance: With so many events and athletes competing, there's always a possibility of unexpected results. Given these factors, it seems quite possible that at least 5 countries could win their first Olympic medal in Paris 2024. The historical precedent shows that it's not uncommon for 3-5 countries to achieve this in a single Olympics. With new sports, continued development of Olympic programs in various countries, and the large number of nations still seeking their first medal, the chances appear favorable. However, it's not a certainty. The more established sporting nations still dominate many events, and breakthrough performances are still relatively rare. The target of 5 countries is also at the higher end of what we've seen in recent Games. Considering all these factors, I would estimate the probability to be moderately high, but not overwhelmingly so.

question.title: At the 2024 Olympics, will at least 5 countries win their debut gold medal?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. For example, in Tokyo 2020, only three countries (Bermuda, Philippines, and Qatar) won their first gold medals. 2. Number of countries yet to win gold: As of 2023, there are still over 70 countries that have never won an Olympic gold medal. This provides a large pool of potential first-time winners. 3. Emerging sports powerhouses: Some countries have been investing heavily in their Olympic programs and have come close to gold in recent games. For example, San Marino won its first medals (silver and bronze) in Tokyo 2020. 4. New Olympic sports: The 2024 Olympics will feature breaking (breakdancing) as a new sport, which could provide opportunities for countries with strong urban dance cultures to win their first gold. 5. Short time frame: The question is asking about a single Olympic Games, not a series of games over time, which makes it less likely for multiple countries to achieve this milestone simultaneously. 6. Competitive nature of the Olympics: The Olympics gather the world's best athletes, making it extremely challenging for countries without a strong sporting tradition to suddenly win gold. 7. COVID-19 impact: The pandemic may have affected training and preparation for some countries more than others, potentially leveling the playing field somewhat. Given these factors, while it's certainly possible for 5 or more countries to win their first gold medal in Paris 2024, it seems unlikely. The historical precedent suggests that 1-3 countries winning their first gold in a single Olympics is more common. The introduction of new sports and the large number of countries yet to win gold provide some potential for surprises, but the high level of competition and the short time frame make it challenging for multiple countries to achieve this milestone simultaneously.

question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic medal at the Paris Olympics, and (b) 5 or more countries win their first-ever Olympic gold medal at the Paris Olympics, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions).

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: There's growing concern among Democrats about Biden's age and electability, as evidenced by the Politico report mentioned. 2. Existing dissent: Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden to drop out, and two endangered Democrats have expressed pessimism about his chances. 3. Behind-the-scenes activity: Multiple drafts of letters are reportedly circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling for Biden to end his campaign. 4. Time frame: The question asks about this happening before July 20th, which is about 2.5 weeks from now. This is a relatively short period for such a significant political move. 5. Political risk: Publicly calling for the incumbent president of your own party to drop out is a major political risk. Many Democrats might be hesitant to do this, fearing backlash or division within the party. 6. Biden's stance: Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election and hasn't shown signs of considering dropping out. 7. Party unity concerns: The Democratic leadership might work to prevent such a public call to avoid damaging party unity ahead of the election. 8. Precedent: It's unusual for sitting members of Congress to publicly call for their party's incumbent president not to run for re-election. Given these factors, while there is clearly some dissatisfaction and behind-the-scenes activity, it seems unlikely that a group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators will publicly pressure Biden to drop out in such a short timeframe. The political risks and potential for party disunity are significant deterrents. However, the existence of draft letters and the reported behind-the-scenes activity suggest it's not impossible. If the drafts gain traction quickly or if there's a sudden, significant event that changes the political calculus, it could happen.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Current intentions: As of now (July 2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He has already launched his re-election campaign and is actively fundraising. 3. Age and health concerns: Biden is currently 80 years old and would be 82 at the start of a second term. While his health appears stable, concerns about his age and stamina persist among some voters and party members. 4. Approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, hovering around 40-45%. However, this alone is not typically enough to deter an incumbent from seeking re-election. 5. Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden. There is no strong alternative candidate actively challenging him for the nomination. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely that a sitting president would wait until so late in the process to decline the nomination. 7. Political landscape: The Republican field is still taking shape, and Biden may see himself as the strongest candidate to face potential Republican nominees. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he won't accept the nomination before July 15, 2024. He has already committed to running, has party support, and there are no clear indications of a change in this stance. The only scenarios where this might happen would be a sudden, severe health issue or an unforeseen political scandal, both of which are relatively low-probability events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this combined event occurring, we need to consider both parts separately and then evaluate their joint probability. (a) A group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or US Senators pressuring Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024: This scenario is possible but unlikely. While there has been some concern about Biden's age and approval ratings, there is currently no significant public movement within the Democratic Party to push him out. Most Democratic leaders are publicly supporting Biden's re-election bid. The timeframe (by July 20, 2024) is relatively short for such a dramatic change to occur. (b) Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination: This is even less likely than part (a). The deadline of July 15, 2024, is very close to the Democratic National Convention, making such a late withdrawal even more improbable. The pressure from Democratic leaders (a) would need to precede Biden's announcement (b), and both would need to occur before their respective deadlines. Given the current political landscape, Biden's stated intentions, and the short timeframe, the probability of both these events occurring as specified is extremely low.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) "ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, and (2) the linked market get at least 377 traders by the end of July 15, 2024?
question.body:
(1) The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

(2) Resolves YES if the market embedded above has 377 traders before market close (July 15, 11:59 PM Pacific Time). Resolves NO otherwise.

ChatGPT's availability in the EU on June 30, 2024: ChatGPT is currently available in most EU countries, with some temporary exceptions in the past (like Italy). OpenAI has shown a commitment to complying with EU regulations and addressing privacy concerns. By June 2024, it's likely that any current issues will be resolved, and ChatGPT will be generally available across the EU. The EU's Digital Services Act and AI Act are expected to be in full effect by then, and OpenAI is likely to have adapted its services to comply with these regulations. Therefore, this condition has a high probability of being met. 2. The market reaching 377 traders by July 15, 2024: This condition is more uncertain. The market's current number of traders is not provided, nor is there information about its growth rate or popularity. Without this information, it's difficult to make a precise estimate. However, given that the market has over a year to reach this goal (from May 2023 to July 2024), and considering that AI and ChatGPT are topics of growing interest, it's plausible that the market could attract 377 traders. Still, this is less certain than the first condition. Combining these two conditions, we need both to occur for a YES resolution. The first condition seems highly likely, while the second is less certain but still possible. Given the uncertainty around the second condition, we should be cautious in our overall estimate.

question.title: Will Latvia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Latvia does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Latvia's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Latvia has had mixed results in Eurovision. They last qualified for the final in 2016, and have failed to qualify in the last seven contests (2017-2023). This suggests a recent struggle to make it through the semi-finals. 2. Selection process: Latvia typically uses a national selection show called Supernova to choose their entry. The quality of their selection process can impact their chances. 3. Competition level: The overall quality of entries from other countries in their semi-final will affect Latvia's chances of qualifying. 4. Voting patterns: Latvia often receives support from neighboring Baltic countries and the Nordic region, which can help in the semi-finals. 5. Song quality and performance: While we don't know the specifics of Latvia's 2024 entry yet, the quality of the song and stage performance are crucial factors. 6. Changes in Eurovision voting system: Any potential changes to the voting system could impact Latvia's chances. 7. Time for preparation: With the question being asked in April 2024, Latvia has time to refine their entry and performance before the contest in May. Given Latvia's recent struggle to qualify, their chances are not particularly high. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and with a strong entry and performance, they could potentially break their non-qualification streak. The fact that they consistently participate and have qualified in the past shows they have the potential to do so again. Considering all these factors, I would estimate that Latvia has a below-average but not negligible chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Strategic importance: Chasiv Yar is strategically important due to its location west of Bakhmut, which Russia captured in May 2023. Taking Chasiv Yar would allow Russia to push further into Donetsk Oblast. 3. Time frame: The question asks about the situation approximately 13 months from now, which is a significant amount of time in terms of military operations. 4. Recent Russian tactics: Russia has been focusing on attritional warfare and slow, grinding advances rather than rapid offensives. 5. Ukrainian defenses: Ukraine has been fortifying positions in the area and has shown resilience in defending key locations. 6. International support: Continued Western support for Ukraine could impact their ability to hold the line, but the level of future support is uncertain. 7. Russian resources: Russia has shown the ability to sustain long-term military operations, but their resources are not unlimited. 8. Potential for negotiations: There's always a possibility of peace talks or ceasefire agreements, which could freeze the front lines. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that Russia could take control of Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024, but it's far from certain. The extended timeframe gives Russia more opportunity to make advances, and Chasiv Yar's proximity to current Russian-held territory makes it a likely target. However, Ukrainian resistance and potential international support could prevent this outcome.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extremely low approval ratings. 2. Current situation: Biden is already the oldest president in U.S. history, and concerns about his age and mental acuity have been raised. However, he has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. 3. Democratic Party support: The party leadership has generally rallied behind Biden, and there is no strong alternative candidate being promoted within the party. 4. Timing: The question's deadline (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, which is typically held in August. It would be highly unusual for a sitting president to withdraw so late in the process. 5. Recent statements: Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election. In April 2023, he officially announced his 2024 campaign. 6. Political landscape: While Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, they are not at a catastrophic level that would typically force an incumbent to step aside. 7. Potential for unforeseen events: There is always a possibility of unexpected health issues or major political scandals, but these are relatively low-probability events. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024. The only realistic scenarios where this might happen would be a severe health crisis or an extremely damaging political scandal, both of which are relatively low-probability events.

Biden's performance and approval ratings: While Biden's approval ratings have been low, they haven't reached a level that would typically prompt such drastic action from his own party. 5. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that 10 or more Democratic Senators would call for Biden to drop out before July 20. Organizing debates could be seen as divisive and potentially harmful to the party's chances in the general election. 4. While names like Harris, Newsom, and Whitmer are mentioned, they have not indicated any intention to run against Biden. 5. Biden's campaign strategy: Given his incumbency and age, Biden's campaign might prefer to limit public appearances and debates to minimize potential gaffes or concerns about his fitness for office. 6. Precedent: In recent history, when an incumbent president is running for re-election, their party typically does not hold primary debates. 7. DNC's stance: The Democratic National Committee would likely discourage any debates that could potentially weaken the incumbent president's position. However, we must also consider some factors that could increase the likelihood of a debate: 1. Public or party pressure: If there were significant concerns about Biden's candidacy (e.g., health issues), there might be calls for alternatives to be presented through a debate format. 3. Unexpected events: Major political developments or crises could potentially change the dynamics of the race. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for a debate to occur, it seems highly unlikely. The combination of Biden's incumbency, the short timeframe, the lack of announced challengers, and the party's likely desire for unity make a debate improbable.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]

question.body:

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 years old at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There have been ongoing concerns about his age and mental acuity, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current statements and actions: As of now (early 2024), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has taken steps consistent with a re-election campaign, including fundraising and building campaign infrastructure. 4. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns about his age, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there is no strong alternative candidate emerging to challenge him for the nomination. 5. Political landscape: The Republican field is still taking shape, and Biden may see himself as the strongest candidate to defeat potential Republican nominees, particularly if former President Trump is the GOP nominee. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is relatively close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely that Biden would wait until so late in the process to announce he's not running, as it would leave the party scrambling to find an alternative nominee. 7. Historical precedent: The last incumbent president to not seek re-election was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, and that decision was made much earlier in the election cycle. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden will announce he's not accepting the nomination before July 15, 2024. He has given no indication of such intentions, and barring a significant health issue or unforeseen political development, he is likely to continue his re-election campaign.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. question.title: Will Donald Trump be charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024?
question.body: The question resolves **Yes** if Donald Trump is charged or indicted for any statements related to potential witnesses in *[The State of Georgia v. Donald J. Trump, et al](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecution_of_Donald_Trump_in_Georgia)*. The indictments must occur before June 1, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump being charged with witness tampering in Georgia before June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1.
