question.title: If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance?
question.body:
Question resolves YES if a big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc.

Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient.

This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Likelihood of Joe Biden dropping out: Currently, there's no strong indication that Biden intends to drop out of the 2024 presidential race. He has announced his re-election campaign and seems committed to running. However, factors like health concerns or political pressure could potentially change this. 2. Media landscape and competition: Major media outlets are in fierce competition to break significant news stories first. If there were hints of Biden dropping out, these outlets would be highly motivated to report on it as soon as possible. 3. White House information control: The White House typically tries to control the narrative around major announcements. They would likely attempt to prevent leaks about such a significant decision. 4. Time frame for leaks: Six hours is a relatively short time in political news cycles. While it's possible for information to leak this quickly, it's not guaranteed, especially for such a momentous decision. 5. Reliability of sources: The question specifies that the report must come from a reliable major outlet. These organizations typically require strong confirmation before reporting such significant news, which could delay reporting. 6. Historical precedent: There's no recent precedent for a sitting president dropping out of a re-election race, making it difficult to predict how such news would unfold. Given these factors, if Biden were to drop out, there's a moderate to high chance that a major outlet would report it at least 6 hours in advance. The competitive nature of news media and the significance of the story make early reporting likely. However, the short time frame and the potential for tight information control by the White House somewhat reduce this probability.

question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Family dynamics: It's highly unlikely that both Donald Trump Sr. and Jr. would run in the same election cycle, as this would split their base and potentially harm the family's political brand. 3. Political experience: Donald Trump Jr. has never held public office, which would be a significant disadvantage in a presidential race. Typically, nominees have experience as governors, senators, or high-ranking officials. 4. Name recognition: While Trump Jr. has a high profile due to his father's presidency, he doesn't have the same level of recognition or support as his father among Republican voters. 5. Party preferences: The Republican Party typically favors candidates with more traditional political backgrounds or those who have proven their ability to win elections. 6. Time until convention: With the Republican National Convention still over a year away, there's time for the political landscape to change, but major shifts would be needed for Trump Jr. to become a serious contender. 7. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a president's child to immediately succeed them as a major party nominee, with no clear precedent in modern US politics. Given these factors, it appears highly improbable that Donald Trump Jr. would be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require a series of unlikely events and a dramatic shift in the current political landscape.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance? (b) Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) The first part resolves YES if a major and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers President Joe Biden's dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before he officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc. This part resolves as N/A if Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

(b) The second part resolves YES if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Joe Biden dropping out and media coverage: The likelihood of Joe Biden dropping out of the 2024 presidential race is relatively low. He is the incumbent president and has expressed his intention to run for re-election. However, if he were to drop out, it's highly probable that major media outlets would cover the story well in advance of an official announcement. Media organizations are constantly monitoring political developments and have sources within political circles. Given the significance of such news, it's very likely they would report on it at least 6 hours before an official announcement. I'd estimate the probability of this part occurring at around 0.1 (10%), mainly due to the low likelihood of Biden dropping out. (b) Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee: This scenario is extremely unlikely. While Donald Trump Jr. is a prominent figure in Republican circles, he has not expressed serious intentions to run for president, nor has he held any elected office. The Republican party typically nominates candidates with significant political experience, such as governors, senators, or former high-ranking officials. Moreover, if Donald Trump Sr. decides to run again, it's highly improbable that his son would challenge him for the nomination. Even if Trump Sr. doesn't run, there are many other experienced Republican politicians who would be more likely choices. I'd estimate the probability of this part at around 0.01 (1%). For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.1 * 0.01 = 0.001 or 0.1%. This extremely low probability reflects the unlikelihood of both these events occurring together. It's important to note that these events are not entirely independent - if Biden were to drop out, it might slightly increase the chances of an unconventional Republican nominee, but not enough to significantly affect the overall probability.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden dropping out before July 20, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current status: As of now, Joe Biden is the incumbent President and the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. 2. Health concerns: Biden is currently 80 years old and would be 82 at the start of a second term. While he has maintained that he is in good health, his age has been a topic of discussion and concern. 3. Political landscape: Despite some challenges, Biden has not shown any indications of considering dropping out. He has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. 4. Time frame: The resolution date is July 20, 2024, which is relatively close to the election. It would be unusual for a major party candidate to drop out so late in the election cycle without extraordinary circumstances. 5. Historical precedent: It is extremely rare for an incumbent president to drop out of a re-election race. The last time this happened was in 1968 when Lyndon B. Johnson decided not to seek re-election. 6. Party support: The Democratic Party has largely rallied behind Biden, and there is no significant internal challenge to his candidacy. 7. Potential unforeseen events: While unlikely, there is always a possibility of unexpected health issues or major scandals that could force a candidate to drop out. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden will drop out before July 20, 2024. While his age and potential health concerns do introduce some uncertainty, the combination of his incumbent status, party support, and the late stage in the election cycle make it improbable that he would exit the race barring extreme circumstances.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Tucker Carlson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and (b) Biden drop out before July 20?

(b) Biden dropping out before July 20: - Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has announced his intention to run for re-election. - While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for him to step aside, he has remained committed to running. - The Democratic Party has not shown any significant moves to replace him. - Barring unforeseen health issues or major scandals, it's unlikely Biden will drop out. - The probability of Biden dropping out before July 20 is also low, perhaps around 10-15%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these already low probabilities, which results in an extremely low likelihood. Even if we generously estimate each event at 10% probability (which is higher than realistic), the combined probability would be 0.1 * 0.1 = 0.01 or 1%. Given the actual lower likelihoods of each event, especially Carlson becoming the nominee, the true probability is likely even lower than 1%.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Time until the forecast date: July 19, 2024, is more than a year away from the current date. Recent trends: In the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, swimmers were among the top gold medal winners, with Caeleb Dressel and Emma McKeon each winning five golds. Given these factors, it appears highly likely that a swimmer will win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The combination of multiple events, specialization opportunities, and the presence of dominant swimmers in the current competitive landscape strongly favors this outcome. However, there is always the possibility of exceptional performances in other sports or unexpected developments, which prevents us from being absolutely certain.

question.title: Will Malta qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Malta participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If they do not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Malta's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Malta has participated in Eurovision since 1971 and has qualified for the Grand Final in 6 out of the last 10 contests (2013-2023, excluding 2020 which was cancelled). This gives them a 60% qualification rate in recent years. 2. Recent results: Malta qualified for the Grand Final in 2021 and 2023, but failed to qualify in 2022. Their most recent performance in 2023 saw them finish 11th in the Grand Final, which is a strong result. 3. Semi-final draw: The semi-final allocation draw has not yet taken place for 2024, so we don't know which countries Malta will compete against. This can significantly impact their chances. 4. Voting patterns: Malta often receives support from countries like Italy and Australia due to diaspora voting, which can help in the semi-finals. 6. Competition level: The overall quality of entries in their semi-final will affect Malta's chances, but this is unknown at this time. 7. Staging and performance: Malta has generally had good staging in recent years, which helps their qualification chances. 8. Eurovision rule changes: Any potential changes to the voting system or qualification rules could impact Malta's chances, but no major changes have been announced for 2024. Given Malta's recent track record of qualifying more often than not, their strong performance in 2023, and their generally competitive entries, I believe they have a good chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in 2024. Considering all these factors, I estimate that Malta has a slightly better than even chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

Growth potential: Nvidia has been experiencing rapid growth due to the AI boom and its dominance in the GPU market. It has shown impressive year-over-year growth rates. However, sustaining such high growth rates becomes increasingly difficult as a company gets larger. Apple, while a mature company, still has growth potential in services and potentially new product categories (e.g., AR/VR headsets). 3. Market trends: The AI and machine learning trends are likely to continue, which could benefit Nvidia. However, these trends are already priced into Nvidia's valuation to some extent. 4. Economic factors: Global economic conditions, interest rates, and potential recessions could affect both companies, but possibly in different ways. 5. Competition: Nvidia faces increasing competition in the AI chip market from companies like AMD and potentially Apple itself with its own chip designs. 6. Time frame: The question is set for about 10 months from now, which is a relatively short time for such a significant market cap shift to occur. 7. Historical precedent: It's rare for companies to overtake Apple in market cap, and when it has happened (e.g., Microsoft, Saudi Aramco), it has typically been temporary. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Nvidia to surpass Apple in market cap by July 2024, it seems unlikely. Nvidia would need to continue its explosive growth while Apple would need to stagnate or decline significantly. The short time frame makes this even less likely.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but they have rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. The most prominent cases are in Colorado and Minnesota, where lawsuits have been filed. 3. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal proceedings to unfold and potentially reach higher courts. 4. Political climate: The use of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump is highly controversial and politically charged, which could influence decision-making processes. 5. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently, increasing the chances that at least one state might remove Trump from the ballot. 6. Trump's actions on January 6th: The argument for disqualification hinges on whether Trump's actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot constitute 'engaging in insurrection or rebellion' against the United States. 7. Potential Supreme Court involvement: Given the high-stakes nature of this issue, it's likely that any successful attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would be appealed to the Supreme Court, which could make a ruling that applies nationwide. 8. Historical reluctance: Courts have historically been reluctant to interfere with ballot access for major candidates, especially for the presidency. Considering these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that at least one state might attempt to remove Trump from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. However, the likelihood of this attempt being successful and withstanding legal challenges by July 15, 2024, is lower. The unprecedented nature of such an action, combined with the potential for higher court intervention, makes it more likely that Trump will remain on the ballots in most, if not all, states. That said, given the multiple ongoing efforts and the potential for varying interpretations across different states, there is a non-trivial possibility that at least one state might succeed in removing Trump from the ballot by the specified date.

If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

The question resolves No if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Nvidia's market cap vs. Apple's on July 17, 2024: As of September 2023, Apple's market cap is significantly larger than Nvidia's (Apple ~$2.7 trillion vs. Nvidia ~$1.1 trillion). For Nvidia to surpass Apple, it would need to more than double its value while Apple remains stagnant, or grow even more if Apple continues to increase in value. While Nvidia has shown impressive growth due to AI advancements, overtaking Apple in less than a year seems unlikely. However, given Nvidia's momentum in the AI space, it's not impossible. Given the controversial nature of this move and the likely legal challenges, I'd estimate the probability of this occurring in at least one state by July 15, 2024, at about 30%. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health status: As of now, there are no publicly known severe health issues that would warrant invoking Section 4. Biden, while the oldest serving president, has maintained an active schedule and has not shown signs of severe incapacitation. 2. Political climate: The invocation of the 25th Amendment Section 4 is an extremely serious and rare action. It would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree on this drastic step, which would likely cause significant political upheaval. 3. Historical precedent: The 25th Amendment Section 4 has never been invoked in U.S. history, highlighting its extraordinary nature. 4. Time frame: The question specifies a relatively short time frame (about one month from the creation date to the resolution date), which further reduces the likelihood of such a significant event occurring. 5. Context provided: The mention of a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment is more indicative of political posturing than a genuine threat to Biden's presidency. Such calls from opposition party members are not uncommon and rarely lead to action. 6. Upcoming election: With the 2024 presidential election approaching, invoking the 25th Amendment would be seen as an extreme measure that could severely impact the Democratic Party's chances. There would be strong resistance within the party to such a move. 7. Biden's support within his administration: There are no public indications that Biden's Cabinet or Vice President Harris are considering such an action. In fact, they have consistently supported the President. Given these factors, the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is extremely low. While it's not impossible due to unforeseen circumstances, the combination of political, historical, and practical factors make it highly unlikely.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health status: As of July 2024, Joe Biden is 81 years old and generally in good health for his age. He undergoes regular medical check-ups, and no severe health issues have been reported recently. 2. Life expectancy: The average life expectancy for an 81-year-old American male is about 7-8 more years. While this doesn't guarantee anything, it suggests that sudden death is not highly probable. 3. Presidential protection: As the President of the United States, Biden receives excellent medical care and is under constant protection, which reduces the risk of accidents or undetected health issues. 4. Short time frame: The question asks about a very short time frame - approximately three weeks from the creation date to the resolution date. The probability of death occurring in such a brief period is generally low for someone not suffering from a terminal illness. 5. No known imminent threats: There are no publicly known severe health issues or imminent threats to Biden's life that would significantly increase the likelihood of his death in the next few weeks. 6. Historical precedent: No U.S. president has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and none have died of natural causes in office since Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1945. Given these factors, the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, is very low. While it's not impossible due to his advanced age and the unpredictable nature of life, there's no specific reason to believe his death is likely in this short time frame.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, and (b) Joe Biden dies before July 26th, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To resolve YES, both conditions (a) and (b) must occur, which makes this a compound probability question. Let's analyze each part separately and then combine them: (a) Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: This is an extremely rare event that has never occurred in U.S. history. The 25th Amendment Section 4 has never been invoked. While Biden is the oldest president in U.S. history, there have been no serious indications of incapacitation that would warrant such an extreme measure. His administration and party have consistently supported his capability to serve. The probability of this occurring is very low. (b) Joe Biden dying before July 26th, 2024: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While advanced age does increase mortality risk, Biden has access to excellent healthcare and appears to be in relatively good health for his age. The average life expectancy for an 80-year-old American male is about 8 more years. The probability of him dying in the next year (until July 2024) is higher than average due to his age, but still relatively low. Combining these probabilities: For the question to resolve YES, both of these unlikely events must occur. The probability of two independent events both occurring is the product of their individual probabilities, which would result in an extremely low probability. Moreover, if Biden were to die before July 26th, 2024 (condition b), it would preclude the possibility of him being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment (condition a), as the amendment applies only to a living president. This logical impossibility further reduces the probability to essentially zero.

Potential events: We should consider any known upcoming events that could impact the polls, such as debates or major policy announcements. However, no such events are mentioned in the prompt. 5. Given that Trump's lead is already at 2.4 points, which is within the range we're looking for, and considering the short time frame and typical poll stability, there's a good chance the lead will remain within this range. However, there's also a significant possibility it could move slightly above or below this range. The question asks for a very specific range (greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3), which narrows the probability. There's a real chance the lead could dip just below 2 or rise just above 3, which would result in a 'NO' resolution. Considering all these factors, I estimate there's a moderate chance the lead will be in this specific range on July 15.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face significant challenges within their own party. 2. Current political landscape: As of the question's creation date (July 8, 2024), there have been no major challengers to Biden's nomination, and the Democratic Party has generally rallied behind him. 3. Time until convention: With the convention likely to be held in July or August 2024, there is very little time for a serious challenger to emerge and gain enough support to force a brokered convention. 4. Party unity: The Democratic Party has shown a strong desire for unity to present a united front against the Republican nominee. This makes it less likely for factions within the party to push for alternative candidates. 5. Historical precedent: Brokered conventions are extremely rare in modern American politics. The last truly brokered convention for either major party was in 1952 for the Democrats. 6. Delegate allocation rules: The Democratic Party's proportional allocation of delegates makes it difficult for challengers to accumulate enough delegates to prevent a first-ballot nomination. 7. Biden's performance: While there have been concerns about Biden's age and some policy issues, his administration has not faced any catastrophic failures that would prompt a large-scale revolt within the party. Given these factors, it is highly unlikely that the Democrats will have a brokered convention in 2024. The probability of this occurring is very low. While not impossible, it would require an extraordinary and unexpected turn of events to prevent Biden from securing the nomination on the first ballot.

Given that Trump is already leading by 2.4 points, it's quite possible that this lead could increase slightly to fall within the 2-4 point range. Recent trends: The war has been characterized by slow, grinding advances and occasional successful counteroffensives. Ukrainian resistance: Ukraine has demonstrated strong defensive capabilities and has received ongoing support from Western allies, which could help maintain their positions. 7. Potential for negotiations: While currently unlikely, there's always a possibility of peace talks or ceasefires that could freeze the front lines before June 2024. 8. Seasonal factors: Military operations might be affected by weather conditions, with potential offensives more likely in spring or summer 2024. Given these factors, I believe there's a significant chance that Russia could capture Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024, but it's far from certain. The time frame allows for potential Russian advances, especially considering their focus on the Donetsk region. However, Ukrainian defenses and the strategic importance of the town make it a challenging target.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that requires consideration of several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates, but they have rarely been successful. The most notable recent case was the attempt to remove Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ballot in Georgia, which failed. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in multiple states to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. The most prominent case is in Colorado, where a lawsuit has been filed to this effect. 3. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal challenges to be filed, heard, and potentially appealed through various courts. 4. Political climate: The use of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump is highly controversial and politically charged. It's likely to face significant opposition and legal challenges. 5. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently, increasing the chances that at least one state might take this action. 6. Trump's legal troubles: Trump is facing multiple criminal indictments, which could potentially strengthen arguments for his disqualification under the 14th Amendment. 7. Supreme Court: Given the high-stakes nature of such a decision, it's likely that any successful attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would be quickly appealed to the Supreme Court. The current conservative majority might be skeptical of such an application of the 14th Amendment. 8. Historical precedent: The 14th Amendment has never been used to disqualify a former president from running again, which might make courts hesitant to set such a significant precedent. Given these factors, I believe there is a non-trivial chance that at least one state might attempt to remove Trump from the ballot using the 14th Amendment. However, the legal and political hurdles are significant, and it's more likely than not that such attempts would fail or be overturned before the resolution date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024? (b) Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:

- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine
- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours
- Assessed Russian Control
- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine
- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location

The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:

- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours
- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives
- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare
- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine our assessments. (a) Russian control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024: Chasiv Yar is a strategically important town in the Donetsk Oblast of Ukraine, close to Bakhmut. As of September 2023, it is under Ukrainian control, but Russian forces have been attempting to advance in this direction. However, predicting the state of control nearly 9 months into the future is challenging due to the dynamic nature of the conflict. Factors to consider: 1. The slow pace of Russian advances in the region over the past year. 2. Ukraine's demonstrated ability to hold defensive positions. 3. The potential for shifts in military aid to Ukraine from Western allies. 4. Possible changes in Russian military strategy or resource allocation. Given the current situation and historical trends, it seems unlikely that Russia will control Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024, but it's not impossible. (b) Donald Trump being removed or blocked from primary ballots under the 14th Amendment: This is a complex legal and political issue. Several factors to consider: 1. There have been efforts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running for office due to his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot. 2. As of September 2023, no state has successfully removed Trump from the ballot on these grounds. 3. The legal interpretation of Section 3's applicability to a former president is debated and untested in courts. 4. Any attempt to remove Trump from ballots would likely face significant legal challenges and could reach the Supreme Court. 5. The political implications of such a move could make states hesitant to take this action. While there's a possibility that some states might attempt to remove Trump from their ballots, the likelihood of this being successfully implemented and maintained by July 15, 2024, seems low. Combining these assessments: For the overall question to resolve as YES, both (a) and (b) need to occur. Given that both events seem unlikely individually, the probability of both occurring together is even lower.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Given these factors, the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is very low. question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Public opinion polls vs. Manifold respondents: The prompt mentions that public opinion polls show Biden losing to Trump, while other Democrats fare better. However, we need to consider if Manifold respondents are representative of the general public. Given that Manifold is a prediction market platform, its users might be more informed or have different political leanings compared to the general population. 2. Specific candidates vs. generic candidates: Generally, generic candidates tend to perform better in polls than specific candidates because people can project their ideal candidate onto the generic option. This suggests that a generic Democrat might perform better than Joe Biden. 3. Current political climate: As of 2023, Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, which could contribute to a preference for a generic Democrat over Biden specifically. 4. The 3% threshold: The question asks if Trump will gain at least 3% when facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat. This is a significant margin, especially in political polling. 5. Manifold user base: Without specific data on Manifold's user demographics, it's hard to predict how they might differ from the general public in their voting preferences. 6. Time until resolution: The polls close on July 6, 2024, which is still some time away. Political landscapes can change significantly in this timeframe. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that Trump will perform better against Biden compared to a generic Democrat among Manifold respondents. However, the 3% threshold is quite high. While I expect some difference, reaching a full 3% is less certain. The specific nature of Biden as a candidate, combined with his current approval ratings, suggests he might underperform compared to a generic Democrat. However, Manifold users might be more politically engaged and have more stable opinions, potentially reducing the gap between Biden and a generic Democrat. Considering all these factors, I believe there's a moderate chance that Trump will gain at least 3% when facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat among Manifold respondents, but it's far from certain.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. The race is generally considered tight. 2. Historical precedent: Incumbent presidents often face challenges in their re-election bids, especially if economic conditions are unfavorable. 3. By this time, both parties will have had their conventions, and the race will be in full swing. 4. Potential for events to impact polling: There's still a year until the poll in question, during which many events could significantly impact public opinion. 5. 538's methodology: 538 is known for its robust polling aggregation and tends to be less volatile than individual polls. 6. Specific range: The question asks about a very narrow range (greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 points lead for Trump). Given these factors, I believe it's unlikely that Trump will have a lead in this specific range. Here's why: - The race is currently close, and while it could shift significantly in Trump's favor, a lead of exactly 3-4 points is a narrow window. - By July 2024, the race is likely to be either very close (within 1-2 points) or have a more significant lead for one candidate (5+ points) as voters solidify their choices. - While Trump could certainly be leading at this point, the specific range is quite restrictive. However, it's not impossible. If Trump gains momentum throughout the campaign but faces some last-minute challenges, or if there's a gradual shift towards Trump that levels off in this range, it could happen.

question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine them. Given that the probability of Cruz being the nominee is extremely low (let's say 0.5% or 0.005) and the probability of the specific polling scenario is also low (let's say 7% or 0.07), the combined probability would be: 0.005 * 0.07 = 0.00035 or 0.035%. This extremely low probability reflects the highly specific and unlikely nature of both conditions being met simultaneously.

question.title:
Will the  CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS)

question.body: This question will resolve based on reporting by the St. Louis Fed here: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VXVCLS. The reported number for July 20, 2024 must be greater than the reported number on July 20, 2023.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors that influence market volatility and compare the current situation with potential future scenarios. Historical context: The CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS) measures expected market volatility over the next three months. It tends to spike during periods of economic uncertainty or market stress. Current economic conditions: As of now (2023), we're experiencing high inflation, rising interest rates, and concerns about a potential recession. These factors have contributed to increased market volatility. Future outlook: By July 2024, some of the current economic pressures may have eased. Central banks might have successfully managed inflation, and the economic outlook could be more stable. However, new geopolitical or economic challenges could also emerge. Mean reversion: Volatility indices tend to revert to their mean over time. If volatility is currently high, there's a chance it might be lower in a year. Unpredictability: Market volatility is inherently difficult to predict, especially over a one-year timeframe. Unexpected events can dramatically shift market sentiment and volatility. Seasonality: While not a strong factor, there can be some seasonal patterns in volatility. However, this effect is usually minimal over a one-year period. Long-term trends: Over very long periods, markets have shown a tendency towards lower volatility as they mature. However, this effect is minimal over a one-year timeframe. Given these factors, it's difficult to say with high confidence whether the VXVCLS will be higher or lower year-over-year. The current economic uncertainties suggest volatility might remain elevated, but there's also a good chance that conditions could improve and volatility could decrease. Considering the tendency of volatility to mean-revert and the possibility of economic conditions stabilizing, I lean slightly towards the probability that volatility will be lower in July 2024 compared to July 2023. However, the uncertainty is high.

question.title: Will the head of the Secret Service resign within the next 90 days?
question.body: Will Kimberly Cheatle, the Director of the U.S. Secret Service, resign, be fired, or for any other reason no longer be the director of the Secret Service before October 12, 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kimberly Cheatle resigning or leaving her position as Director of the U.S. Secret Service within the next 90 days, we need to consider several factors: 1. However, the Secret Service director's role is typically seen as apolitical and not subject to change based on election cycles. 4. Historical precedent: Secret Service directors typically serve for several years. The previous director, James Murray, served from 2019 to 2022. Sudden resignations or dismissals are rare unless there are significant issues. 5. Personal factors: We have no public information about any personal reasons that might lead Cheatle to resign, such as health issues or family matters. 6. Agency stability: The Secret Service has faced challenges in recent years, including security breaches and misconduct allegations. However, Cheatle was brought in partly to address these issues, and a sudden departure could be seen as destabilizing for the agency. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that Kimberly Cheatle would resign or leave her position within the next 90 days. There are no apparent pressures or reasons for her to step down, and stability in leadership is generally preferred, especially in critical security agencies like the Secret Service.

question.body:

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless faced with significant challenges or health issues. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There have been ongoing concerns about his age and mental acuity, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current statements and actions: As of now (July 2023), Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has already launched his 2024 campaign. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there are no significant primary challengers at this time. 5. Political landscape: The Republican field is still taking shape, and Biden may see himself as the strongest candidate to defeat potential Republican nominees. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely for an incumbent to wait this long to announce they're not running. 7. Historical precedent: The last incumbent president to not seek re-election was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, and he announced his decision in March of that year, much earlier than the July 2024 deadline in this question. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination so late in the process. He has already launched his campaign, has party support, and has consistently expressed his intention to run. While age and health concerns are real factors, they don't seem to be deterring him at this point. The only scenario where this might happen is if there's a sudden, severe health issue or an unforeseen political crisis. However, the probability of such an event occurring and leading to this specific outcome within this timeframe is quite low.

question.title: Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?
question.body: Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of another Democratic party presidential debate occurring before the 2024 Democratic National Convention, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee. Typically, when an incumbent president is running for re-election, the party tends to rally behind them, reducing the likelihood of debates with potential challengers. 2. Time frame: The question was created on July 2, 2024, and the resolution date is August 12, 2024. This leaves a relatively short window of about 5-6 weeks for a debate to occur, which is quite limited. 3. Party unity: The Democratic party generally tries to present a united front going into a presidential election, especially when facing a Republican challenger. Debates between potential nominees could be seen as divisive and potentially harmful to the party's chances. 4. Lack of strong challengers: While names like Harris, Newsom, and Whitmer are mentioned, there hasn't been significant momentum or public calls for these individuals to challenge Biden for the nomination. 5. Biden's campaign strategy: Given Biden's age and some concerns about his public appearances, his campaign might prefer to limit his debate exposure, even within the party. 6. Historical precedent: It's uncommon for there to be debates when an incumbent president is running for re-election within their own party. 7. Late stage in the primary process: By July 2024, most primary elections and caucuses would have already taken place, further reducing the need or justification for a debate. However, we must also consider some factors that could increase the probability: 8. Potential health issues: If concerns about Biden's health or cognitive abilities significantly increase, it could prompt calls for a debate. 9. Unexpected challenger: A last-minute, high-profile challenger could potentially force a debate scenario. 10. Party strategy: If the Democratic party leadership becomes concerned about Biden's electability, they might encourage a debate to showcase alternatives. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for a debate to occur, it seems highly unlikely. The combination of Biden's incumbent status, the late stage in the primary process, the short time frame, and the general desire for party unity all work against the likelihood of a debate.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, and will there be another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if, prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination. If such a statement is not made before the deadline, this resolves as No.

(b) Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention? This resolves as Yes if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g., Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden, etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves No otherwise.

The combined question resolves as Yes if both (a) and (b) resolve as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Will Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024? This is highly unlikely for several reasons: 1. Biden has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. 2. As the incumbent president, he has a significant advantage and is the presumptive nominee. 3. The deadline (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, leaving little time for the party to adjust if he were to withdraw. 4. There are no strong indications of health issues or scandals that might force him to step down. I would estimate the probability of this happening at around 5% (0.05). (b) Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention? This is also unlikely because: 1. With Biden as the incumbent and presumptive nominee, the Democratic Party is unlikely to hold debates that could potentially divide the party or weaken Biden's position. 2. Debates are typically held when there's a competitive primary, which is not expected in this case. 3. The DNC has not announced any plans for debates, and it's getting late in the cycle to organize them. However, if Biden were to withdraw (as per part a), the likelihood of debates would increase significantly. Given this contingency, I would estimate the probability of debates occurring at about 15% (0.15). For the combined question to resolve as Yes, both (a) and (b) must occur. To calculate this, we multiply the probabilities: 0.05 * 0.15 = 0.0075 or 0.75%.

question.title: Will Google DeepMind publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: For Google DeepMind, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Google DeepMind publishing a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Google DeepMind's commitment to AI safety: DeepMind has consistently emphasized the importance of AI safety in their research and public communications. They have a dedicated AI safety team and have published numerous papers on the topic. 2. Industry trends: There's an increasing focus on AI safety and transparency across the tech industry, especially for large language models and advanced AI systems. External audits and red-teaming exercises are becoming more common. 3. Regulatory pressure: Governments and regulatory bodies are pushing for more transparency and safety measures in AI development. This external pressure might encourage DeepMind to conduct and publish such reports. 4. Timeline: The question gives a deadline of June 30, 2024, which is about a year from now. This provides ample time for DeepMind to plan, execute, and publish such a report. 5. DeepMind's past behavior: While DeepMind has published safety-related research, they haven't typically released detailed external red-teaming reports for their models. However, the AI landscape is rapidly evolving, and past behavior may not be indicative of future actions. 6. Competition: Other major AI companies like OpenAI have published similar reports, which might incentivize DeepMind to do the same to maintain their reputation as a leader in responsible AI development. 7. Potential drawbacks: Publishing such a report could expose vulnerabilities in their models, which might make DeepMind hesitant. However, the benefits of transparency and building trust might outweigh these concerns. Considering these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that Google DeepMind will publish such a report by the given deadline. The increasing emphasis on AI safety, regulatory pressures, and industry trends all point towards this outcome. However, there's still significant uncertainty due to the potential strategic reasons for not publishing such a report and DeepMind's past practices.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current availability: As of now (May 2023), ChatGPT is generally available in most EU countries, with some exceptions like Italy (which temporarily banned it but later allowed it with conditions). 2. OpenAI's commitment to the EU market: OpenAI has shown interest in maintaining and expanding its presence in the EU, working to address concerns raised by regulators. 3. EU regulations: The EU is developing AI regulations, including the AI Act, which may impact ChatGPT's availability. However, these regulations are likely to focus on transparency, safety, and accountability rather than outright bans. 4. Time frame: The question is about availability more than a year from now, giving OpenAI ample time to adapt to any new regulations or requirements. 5. OpenAI's track record: The company has demonstrated a willingness to work with regulators and adapt its products to meet local requirements. 6. Potential for alternatives: Even if the current version of ChatGPT faces restrictions, OpenAI might develop a modified version that complies with EU regulations. 7. Public demand: There is significant public interest in AI tools like ChatGPT, which could influence regulators to find ways to keep such services available while addressing concerns. 8. Competition: Other AI companies are likely to enter the market, potentially setting precedents for operating in the EU that OpenAI could follow. Given these factors, it seems highly likely that ChatGPT or a similar OpenAI service will be generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024. The main risks are potential regulatory hurdles, but OpenAI has both the time and the motivation to address these. There's a small chance of temporary unavailability due to unforeseen circumstances, but the overall outlook is positive.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the International Criminal Court (ICC) issuing arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. ICC's jurisdiction: The ICC has jurisdiction over war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. Israel is not a party to the Rome Statute, but Palestine is, which gives the ICC potential jurisdiction over crimes committed in Palestinian territories. 2. Ongoing investigation: The ICC has already opened an investigation into alleged war crimes in the Palestinian territories, including those potentially committed by Israeli officials. 3. Current conflict: The ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict since October 2023 has led to numerous allegations of war crimes and violations of international law, particularly regarding the high number of civilian casualties in Gaza. 4. International pressure: There has been increasing international pressure on Israel regarding its conduct in the conflict, with many countries and organizations calling for investigations into potential war crimes. 5. ICC's historical approach: The ICC has previously issued arrest warrants for sitting heads of state and high-ranking officials in other conflicts, showing willingness to pursue such actions. 6. Time frame: The question gives a deadline of July 1, 2024, which is about 17 months from now. This is a significant amount of time for investigations to progress and for the ICC to make decisions. 7. Political considerations: Issuing arrest warrants for Israeli leaders would be a highly controversial move that could face significant opposition from Israel's allies, particularly the United States. 8. Evidence gathering: The ICC would need to gather substantial evidence to justify issuing arrest warrants, which can be challenging in ongoing conflict situations. Given these factors, I believe there is a moderate probability that the ICC will issue arrest warrants for at least one of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024. The ongoing conflict, existing investigation, and international pressure increase the likelihood. However, political considerations and the challenges of evidence gathering in an active conflict zone may slow down the process.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a terrorist act occurring in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical context: France has experienced several terrorist attacks in recent years, including the 2015 Paris attacks and the 2016 Nice truck attack. This history suggests an ongoing threat. 2. High-profile nature of the Olympics: Major international events like the Olympics are often seen as attractive targets for terrorist organizations due to their global visibility and symbolic importance. 3. Security measures: French authorities are likely to implement extensive security measures during the Olympics, which could deter potential attacks. However, the scale of the event also presents challenges in maintaining comprehensive security. 4. Current global tensions: Geopolitical situations, such as conflicts in the Middle East or other regions, could potentially motivate extremist groups to carry out attacks. 5. Intelligence capabilities: French and international intelligence agencies will be on high alert during the Olympics, potentially increasing the chances of preventing attacks. 6. Timeframe: The question covers a relatively short period (17 days), which limits the window of opportunity for potential attackers. 7. Definition of terrorist attack: The resolution criteria are quite broad, including any event described as a terrorist attack by French officials that results in at least one injury or death. 8. Recent trends: While France has improved its counter-terrorism efforts, the threat of lone-wolf attacks or small-scale incidents remains a concern. Considering these factors, I believe there is a significant risk of a terrorist act occurring during the Olympics in France. The high-profile nature of the event, combined with France's history of attacks and the broad definition of what constitutes a terrorist act for this question, increases the likelihood. However, the short timeframe and expected heightened security measures do mitigate the risk to some extent.

ICC issuing arrest warrants for listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024: The ICC has been investigating alleged war crimes in Palestinian territories, and there's been increasing international pressure on Israel due to the ongoing conflict in Gaza. However, issuing arrest warrants for top Israeli officials would be a significant and politically sensitive move. While the ICC has shown willingness to pursue high-profile cases (e.g., the arrest warrant for Russian President Putin), Israel is not a member of the ICC, which complicates matters. The timeframe (before July 1, 2024) also limits the likelihood. I'd estimate this probability at around 0.2 or 20%. 2. Terrorist act in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics: Major international events like the Olympics can be targets for terrorist activities. France has experienced terrorist attacks in the past and maintains a high level of security awareness. The specific timeframe (July 26 to August 11, 2024) and location (metropolitan France) narrow the window for such an event. While French security services will be on high alert, the influx of visitors and global attention could potentially create opportunities for extremists. I'd estimate this probability at around 0.15 or 15%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.2 * 0.15 = 0.03 or 3%. question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?

This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 5, 2024, Trump is leading Biden by 2.4 points according to 538's national polling average. This is within the range specified in the question (greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3). 2. Time frame: We're looking at the polling average on July 15, 2024, which is only 10 days from the last known data point. This is a relatively short period in political polling, suggesting that dramatic shifts are less likely. 3. Historical volatility: Presidential polling averages tend to be relatively stable in the months leading up to an election, with most changes being gradual rather than sudden. 4. Potential events: There's always a possibility of major events occurring that could shift polling numbers, but without specific information about such events, we should assume relative stability. 5. Margin of error: Polls typically have a margin of error, which means small fluctuations are common and expected. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current 2.4 point lead is seen as somewhat of an outlier, there might be a slight tendency for the numbers to move back towards a longer-term average. Given these factors, it seems quite plausible that Trump's lead could remain within the specified range. The current lead is already within this range, and while it could certainly move outside of it, the short timeframe and typical polling stability suggest a good chance of it staying within this narrow band. However, we must also consider that the range is quite narrow (only 1 percentage point), which makes it less likely to hit exactly this target. There's a significant chance the lead could shrink below 2 points or grow beyond 3 points.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, and (b) Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

(b) The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.
