For both conditions to be met, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.30 * 0.40 = 0.12 or 12%.

question.title: Will the Orlando Magic win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Orlando Magic are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Orlando Magic winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current team performance: As of the 2023-24 season, the Orlando Magic are not considered a top-tier team in the NBA. They have been in a rebuilding phase for several years and have not made the playoffs since the 2019-20 season. 2. Young talent: The Magic have some promising young players like Paolo Banchero, Franz Wagner, and Jalen Suggs. However, these players are still developing and lack significant playoff experience. 3. Competition: The NBA is highly competitive, with several powerhouse teams like the Denver Nuggets, Boston Celtics, Milwaukee Bucks, and Golden State Warriors. These teams have more established stars and recent playoff success. 4. Historical performance: The Orlando Magic have never won an NBA championship in their franchise history. They have only made it to the NBA Finals twice (1995 and 2009), losing both times. 5. Time for improvement: While the question resolves in June 2024, which gives the team some time to improve, it's unlikely they can make such a dramatic leap to become championship contenders in less than a year. 6. Coaching and management: The Magic have a relatively new head coach in Jamahl Mosley, who is still proving himself at the NBA level. The team's management has been focused on rebuilding through the draft, which typically takes several years to yield championship-level results. 7. Eastern Conference competition: Even if the Magic improve significantly, they would have to overcome strong Eastern Conference teams like the Bucks, Celtics, and Philadelphia 76ers to reach the Finals. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that the Orlando Magic will win the 2024 NBA Finals. While they have some promising young talent, they are not currently positioned as serious contenders, and the timeline for their development into a championship-caliber team is likely longer than the period until June 2024.

question.title: Will Malta qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Malta participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If they do not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Malta's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Malta has participated in Eurovision since 1971 and has qualified for the Grand Final in 6 out of the last 10 contests (2013-2023, excluding 2020 which was cancelled). This shows a moderate success rate in recent years. 2. Recent results: Malta qualified for the Grand Final in 2021 and 2023, but failed to qualify in 2022. Their 2023 entry finished 11th in the Grand Final, which is a strong performance. 3. National selection process: Malta typically uses a national final or internal selection to choose their entry. The quality of their selection process can impact their chances. 4. Eurovision trends: The contest often sees voting blocs and neighbor voting, which can affect qualification chances. Malta doesn't benefit significantly from these factors due to its geographical location. 5. Performance quality: Malta has often sent competent performers and well-produced songs, which contributes to their qualification chances. 6. Semi-final draw: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can affect qualification chances, but this information is not available at the time of this assessment. 7. Changes in Eurovision rules or format: Any significant changes to the contest format could impact qualification chances, but no major changes have been announced for 2024 as of now. Given Malta's recent track record of qualifying in 2 out of the last 3 contests, their strong 11th place finish in 2023, and their overall qualification rate of 60% in the past decade, I believe Malta has a slightly better than even chance of qualifying for the Grand Final in 2024. However, the unpredictable nature of the contest and the unknown factors (such as the quality of their 2024 entry and the semi-final draw) prevent me from being overly confident.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Tim Scott becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: As of now, Tim Scott is not a frontrunner in the Republican primary race. He officially announced his candidacy on May 22, 2023, but he's trailing behind more prominent candidates like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis in polls and media attention. 2. Name recognition: While Scott is a U.S. Senator from South Carolina and has gained some national attention, he doesn't have the same level of name recognition as some other candidates, which could be a significant hurdle. 3. Fundraising: Scott has shown some fundraising prowess, but it's unclear if he can compete with the war chests of candidates like Trump or DeSantis. 4. Political experience: As a Senator, Scott has federal-level political experience, which is a positive factor. However, he lacks executive experience that governors or former presidents in the race possess. 5. Demographic appeal: As an African American conservative, Scott could potentially broaden the Republican base, which might be seen as an advantage by some party members. 6. Trump factor: The influence of Donald Trump on the Republican party remains strong. Unless Trump's support significantly wanes or he decides not to run, it will be challenging for other candidates to secure the nomination. 7. Time until convention: There's still a considerable amount of time until the Republican National Convention in 2024. This gives Scott time to build his campaign and gain support, but it also means the political landscape could change significantly. 8. Crowded field: The Republican primary field is likely to be crowded, which could split the vote and make it difficult for any single candidate to emerge as a clear front-runner, especially against established figures like Trump. Given these factors, while Tim Scott has some strengths as a candidate, the odds are currently stacked against him becoming the Republican nominee. He faces significant challenges in overcoming more established and well-known candidates, particularly Donald Trump. However, politics can be unpredictable, and there's still time for dynamics to shift.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

The political landscape can change significantly by July 2024. 2. Historical trends: Incumbent presidents often have an advantage in re-election bids, but this is not always the case. 3. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: FiveThirtyEight is known for its data-driven approach and tends to be more conservative in its predictions compared to other forecasters. 4. Time until the election: July 19, 2024, is still several months before the November 2024 election. At this point, the race may still be relatively close, as many factors can influence public opinion in the months leading up to the election. 5. Current approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, which could impact his chances of re-election. 6. Potential challenges: Both candidates may face challenges (e.g., age concerns, legal issues for Trump) that could affect their standing in the polls. 7. Economic factors: The state of the economy in mid-2024 will likely play a significant role in shaping public opinion. 8. International events: Unforeseen global events could impact the candidates' perceived competence in foreign policy. Given these factors, it's difficult to predict with high certainty how FiveThirtyEight will project the race in July 2024. However, considering the incumbent advantage, the tendency for races to tighten as the election approaches, and FiveThirtyEight's generally cautious approach, I believe there's a slightly higher chance that Biden will be projected as the favorite, albeit by a potentially small margin.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current representation: In the 2019 European Parliament elections, the Greens–EFA won 74 seats out of 751, which placed them 4th among political groups. This is far behind the leading groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). 2. Historical trends: The Greens–EFA has never been the largest group in the European Parliament. Their best performance was in 2019, but they were still significantly behind the leading groups. 3. Recent political climate: While environmental issues have gained prominence in recent years, this hasn't translated into a dominant position for Green parties across Europe. Many traditional center-right and center-left parties have also adopted more environmentally friendly policies. 4. National-level performance: Green parties have seen some success in national elections in countries like Germany and Austria, but they are not the dominant force in most EU member states. 5. Competition: The EPP and S&D have historically been the two largest groups in the European Parliament and have well-established bases of support across multiple countries. 6. Polling: While specific polls for the 2024 European elections are not yet widely available, general trends do not indicate a massive surge in support for Green parties across Europe that would be necessary to overtake the larger groups. 7. Structural challenges: The Greens–EFA would need to more than double their seat count to have a chance at being the largest group, which is an extremely tall order in a single election cycle. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While they may maintain their position or even gain some seats, overtaking the traditionally dominant groups would require an unprecedented and currently unforeseen shift in European politics.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of GUE/NGL holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current position: As of the 2019 European Parliament elections, GUE/NGL (European United Left/Nordic Green Left) holds 39 out of 705 seats, which is about 5.5% of the total. This places them as the smallest group in the European Parliament. 2. Historical performance: GUE/NGL has never been the largest group in the European Parliament since its formation in 1989. They have consistently been one of the smaller groups. 3. Political trends: There hasn't been a significant surge in far-left politics across Europe that would suggest a dramatic increase in support for GUE/NGL parties. 4. Competing groups: Other political groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) have historically held more seats and have a broader base of support across multiple countries. 5. Electoral system: The proportional representation system used in European Parliament elections makes it difficult for smaller parties to suddenly become dominant. 6. Current polling: While specific polls for the 2024 elections are not yet widely available, general political trends do not indicate a massive shift towards far-left parties across Europe. 7. Time until election: While there is still about a year until the elections, which allows for some potential shifts in public opinion, it's unlikely to be enough time for such a dramatic change in the political landscape. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that GUE/NGL will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. They would need to increase their seat count by several times over to compete with the larger groups, which is an extremely unlikely scenario given the current political climate and historical trends.

question.title: Will Will Hurd be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Will Hurd becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: Current standing: Will Hurd is a former U.S. Representative from Texas who has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican nomination. However, he is not currently considered a frontrunner in the race. Name recognition: Compared to other candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley, Hurd has relatively low national name recognition, which is a significant disadvantage in a presidential primary. Fundraising: While exact figures are not provided, Hurd is likely to face challenges in raising the substantial funds required to run a competitive national campaign, especially compared to better-known candidates. Party alignment: Hurd is known for his more moderate stance on some issues, which may appeal to some voters but could be a disadvantage in a Republican primary that often favors more conservative candidates. Time until convention: While there is still time for dynamics to change before the Republican National Convention, it would require a dramatic shift in the race for Hurd to emerge as the nominee. Historical precedent: It is extremely rare for a candidate with such low initial support and name recognition to secure a major party nomination. Given these factors, the probability of Will Hurd becoming the Republican nominee is very low. While not impossible, it would require an extraordinary and unlikely series of events for him to secure the nomination.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump testifying at the hush money trial, we need to consider several factors: 1. Legal strategy: Trump's legal team will likely advise him on whether testifying is in his best interest. Typically, defendants are not required to testify, and many choose not to do so to avoid potential self-incrimination. 2. Trump's personality: He is known for being outspoken and often expresses a desire to defend himself publicly. This might increase the likelihood of him wanting to testify. 3. Precedent: In previous legal matters, Trump has often given depositions but has been less likely to testify in open court. 4. Potential risks: Testifying could expose Trump to cross-examination, which could be risky if he contradicts himself or provides information that could be used against him. 5. Public perception: Trump may view testifying as an opportunity to speak directly to his supporters and the public, which could influence his decision. 6. Advice from counsel: His lawyers will likely advise against testifying due to the risks involved, but Trump has been known to go against legal advice in the past. 7. Trial strategy: The defense team's overall strategy may influence whether they believe Trump's testimony would be beneficial or detrimental to their case. 8. Time until trial: With the resolution date set for June 15, 2024, there is still significant time for circumstances to change or for Trump to make a decision. Considering these factors, it seems that while there are reasons Trump might want to testify, the legal risks and typical advice given to defendants make it less likely. Trump's unpredictability adds an element of uncertainty, but the potential negative consequences of testifying outweigh the benefits in most cases.

question.title: Will an athlete win more than one medal for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete wins at least two medals for tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. This provides multiple opportunities for skilled players to compete and potentially medal in more than one event. 3. Top players' participation: While some top players may choose to skip the Olympics due to scheduling conflicts or other reasons, many elite players view the Olympics as a prestigious event and aim to participate. 4. Team strength: Some countries have particularly strong tennis teams, increasing the likelihood of their players competing (and potentially medaling) in multiple events. Given these factors, it seems quite likely that at least one athlete will win more than one medal in tennis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The multiple event formats provide ample opportunity for skilled players to compete in different categories. Historical precedent shows that this is a common occurrence, and the structure of Olympic tennis events facilitates multiple medal wins for top performers. question.body:

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. The race is generally considered tight. 2. By this time, both parties will have held their conventions, and the race will be in full swing. 4. Given these factors, it's plausible that Trump could have a lead over Biden, but a lead between 3 and 4 points is quite specific and represents a relatively narrow range. While not impossible, it requires a precise set of circumstances to occur. A more likely scenario might be either a closer race (within 3 points) or a larger lead for either candidate. However, the question specifically asks about a lead for Trump between 3 and 4 points. Considering all these factors, I believe there's a chance for this specific outcome, but it's not highly probable. The race could easily be closer or further apart than this range.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current representation: As of 2023, the Greens–EFA group holds 72 out of 705 seats in the European Parliament, making them the 4th largest group. This is significantly behind the largest groups like the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). 2. Historical performance: The Greens–EFA has never been the largest group in the European Parliament. Their best performance was in the 2019 elections, where they gained seats but still remained the 4th largest group. 3. Political trends: While environmental issues have gained prominence in recent years, leading to increased support for Green parties in some national elections, this hasn't translated to dominance at the EU level. 4. Fragmentation of the political landscape: The European Parliament is characterized by multiple political groups, making it difficult for any single group to achieve a dominant position. 5. Voter preferences: While climate change and environmental issues are important to many EU citizens, other concerns such as economic stability, immigration, and security also play significant roles in voting decisions. 6. Competition from other groups: The larger, more established groups like EPP and S&D have broader appeal and stronger infrastructure across multiple countries, making it challenging for the Greens–EFA to overtake them. 7. National political landscapes: The performance of Green parties varies significantly across EU member states, with stronger showings in some countries (like Germany) but weaker performances in others. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections. While they may potentially increase their seat count due to growing environmental concerns, overtaking all other political groups would require an unprecedented and currently unforeseen surge in support across multiple EU countries.

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?

Johnson decided not to seek re-election, but he made this decision much earlier in the election cycle. 6. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would drop out before July 20, 2024. It's likely to remain the governing coalition as long as Macron is President. 5. Potential for change: While changes in the Prime Minister position can occur due to various factors (scandals, policy disagreements, reshuffles), there's no strong indication of an imminent change that would result in a Prime Minister from outside the Together coalition. 6. Time frame: The question asks about the situation on July 30, 2024, which is about 13 months from now. This is a significant amount of time in politics, but not so long that it's likely to see a complete overhaul of the political landscape. Given these factors, it seems more likely than not that the Prime Minister on July 30, 2024, will belong to the Together coalition. The coalition's continued support of Macron's presidency and the absence of any clear signs of major political shifts suggest stability in this regard. However, the uncertainty inherent in politics and the relatively long time frame prevent this from being a near-certainty.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Republicans Party of France (Les Républicains) forms a political alliance with the National Rally for the 2024 French legislative election, and (b) The Prime Minister of France belongs to the Together coalition on July 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Before June 30, 2024, an electoral alliance or coalition agreement is officially announced between the Republicans Party (Les Républicains) and National Rally (Rassemblement National) for the upcoming French legislative election, according to credible sources. (2) The party of the Prime Minister of France is Together on July 30th, 2024, at 12:00 Central European Time, according to credible sources. If either condition is not met, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of both conditions being met. Let's analyze each condition separately: 1. Electoral alliance between Les Républicains and National Rally: This seems highly unlikely for several reasons: a) Les Républicains (LR) is a center-right party, while National Rally (RN) is a far-right party. Their ideologies and policies differ significantly. b) LR has historically maintained a 'cordon sanitaire' against far-right parties, refusing to form alliances with them. c) Such an alliance could alienate moderate LR voters and damage the party's reputation. d) As of now, there are no indications or rumors of such an alliance being considered. 2. Prime Minister from the Together coalition on July 30, 2024: This is more likely, but still uncertain: a) The Together coalition (Ensemble) currently holds power, with Elisabeth Borne as Prime Minister. b) However, the coalition lacks an absolute majority in the National Assembly, making governance challenging. c) There could be political shifts or reshuffles before July 2024, especially considering the European Parliament elections in June 2024. d) The stability of the current government until July 2024 is not guaranteed. For both conditions to be met, we would need to see a dramatic shift in French politics, particularly from the Republicans' side. The likelihood of the first condition is extremely low, while the second condition is more plausible but still uncertain. Given that both conditions must be met for a 'Yes' resolution, and the first condition is highly improbable, the overall likelihood of a 'Yes' resolution is very low.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: Current health and capacity of President Biden: While there have been concerns about Biden's age and occasional verbal gaffes, there's no concrete evidence of severe cognitive decline or incapacitation that would warrant invoking the 25th Amendment. Political climate: The request by a GOP lawmaker for Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment is more likely a political move rather than a genuine concern about Biden's capacity. Such calls from opposition parties are not uncommon and rarely lead to action. Historical precedent: The 25th Amendment Section 4 has never been invoked in U.S. history. Its use is reserved for extreme situations where the President is clearly unable to discharge their duties. Time frame: The question asks about this happening before August 2024, which is a relatively short time frame (about a month from the creation date of this question). Support from Vice President and Cabinet: For Section 4 to be invoked, it would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree. There's no indication that Biden's own administration has any plans or desire to take such a drastic step. Biden's own actions: Biden continues to perform his presidential duties, make public appearances, and engage in complex policy discussions, which contradicts the notion of incapacitation. Safeguards and procedures: The 25th Amendment has built-in safeguards to prevent misuse, including the President's ability to contest the declaration. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. While it's not impossible due to unforeseen health issues that could arise, the probability is very low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extreme unpopularity. Biden has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. While his health has been generally stable, concerns about his age and stamina persist. 3. Current polling and approval ratings: Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, hovering around 40-45%. However, this is not unprecedented for an incumbent at this stage of their presidency. 4. Democratic Party support: Despite some concerns, the Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden's re-election bid. There is no strong alternative candidate pushing for the nomination. 5. Time frame: The question's resolution date is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in July or August). It would be highly unusual and potentially damaging to the party for a sitting president to withdraw so late in the process. 6. Biden's public statements: Biden and his team have consistently reaffirmed his intention to run for re-election. There have been no indications of a change in this stance. 7. Political landscape: The Republican field is still taking shape, and Biden may see himself as the strongest candidate to face potential Republican nominees. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024. While concerns about his age and some dissatisfaction within the party exist, there are no strong indicators that he plans to step aside. The late date of the resolution also makes it improbable that such a major decision would be announced so close to the convention.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 and (2) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body: (1) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count. Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office. (2) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To resolve YES, both conditions must be met, which makes this a low probability event. Let's analyze each condition separately: 1. Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: This is an extremely rare occurrence in U.S. history. The 25th Amendment has never been invoked to remove a president involuntarily. While there have been concerns about Biden's age and occasional gaffes, there's no concrete evidence of incapacitation. The bar for invoking Section 4 is very high, requiring agreement from the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet. Without clear signs of severe incapacitation, this scenario is highly unlikely. 2. Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination: Biden has already announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. While there's been speculation about his age and fitness for office, he and his team have consistently reaffirmed his commitment to running. For him to reverse this decision so close to the election (just a few months before the specified date) would be extremely unusual and potentially damaging to the Democratic Party. It would likely only happen if there were a severe health crisis or scandal, neither of which seems imminent. For both of these unlikely events to occur independently and within the specified timeframes is even more improbable. The scenarios that could lead to both happening (such as a sudden, severe health crisis) are possible but very rare. Given the extreme rarity of either event occurring, let alone both, and the lack of current indicators pointing to such outcomes, the probability of this scenario is very low.

question.title: Will Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Tim Scott becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: As of now, Tim Scott is not a frontrunner in the Republican primary race. Polls consistently show him trailing behind more prominent candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley. 2. Name recognition: While Scott is a U.S. Senator, he doesn't have the same level of national recognition as some other candidates, which could hinder his ability to gain widespread support. 3. Fundraising: Scott has shown decent fundraising abilities, but he's not leading in this aspect compared to top-tier candidates. 4. Policy positions: Scott's policy positions are generally in line with mainstream Republican views, which could help him, but don't necessarily set him apart from the field. 5. Demographic appeal: As an African American conservative, Scott could potentially broaden the Republican Party's appeal, but it's unclear if this will translate into significant primary support. 6. Competition: The field is crowded with well-known figures like Trump and DeSantis, making it difficult for Scott to break through. 7. Time until convention: There's still considerable time until the Republican National Convention, allowing for potential shifts in the political landscape. However, barring any major upheavals, it seems unlikely that Scott will surge to the top of the field. 8. Historical precedent: It's rare for a candidate who isn't leading in polls or fundraising at this stage to eventually secure the nomination. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Tim Scott to become the nominee, it appears highly unlikely at this point. The probability of him securing the nomination is quite low.

question.title: Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Chris Christie is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Chris Christie becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis are widely seen as the frontrunners for the Republican nomination. They have significantly higher polling numbers and name recognition compared to Christie. 2. Christie's political position: Christie has been critical of Trump, which may alienate a significant portion of the Republican base that still strongly supports the former president. This stance could make it difficult for him to gain traction in primary elections. 3. Past performance: Christie ran for the Republican nomination in 2016 but dropped out early after poor showings in New Hampshire and Iowa. His previous attempt did not generate substantial support. 4. Fundraising and resources: Christie would likely struggle to match the fundraising capabilities of candidates like Trump and DeSantis, which is crucial for running a competitive national campaign. 5. Media attention: Christie has not been receiving as much media attention as other potential candidates, which could impact his ability to build momentum and gain supporters. 6. Time until convention: While there is still time before the Republican National Convention in 2024, Christie would need to overcome significant obstacles and gain substantial support in a relatively short period to become a serious contender. 7. Potential for unexpected events: While unlikely, there is always a possibility of major shifts in the political landscape that could benefit Christie, such as scandals affecting other candidates or a significant change in public opinion. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Chris Christie will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, the odds are stacked heavily against him at this point.

question.title: Will both Tim Scott and Chris Christie be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Tim Scott and Chris Christie are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both Tim Scott and Chris Christie being the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical precedent: The Republican Party typically nominates one candidate for President and one for Vice President. It's extremely rare for a party to nominate two candidates for the same position. 2. Current political landscape: As of now, neither Tim Scott nor Chris Christie are frontrunners for the Republican nomination. Other candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley have more support and recognition. 3. Individual candidacies: While Tim Scott has officially announced his candidacy, Chris Christie has not yet formally entered the race (as of May 2023). This already reduces the likelihood of both being nominees. 4. Party dynamics: The Republican Party is unlikely to nominate two moderate candidates from the East Coast (Scott from South Carolina and Christie from New Jersey). They typically aim for geographic and ideological balance. 5. Polling data: Current polls do not show strong support for either Scott or Christie as the presidential nominee, let alone both of them. 6. Convention process: The Republican National Convention uses a delegate system to select nominees. It's highly improbable that the delegates would choose two presidential nominees instead of one president and one vice president. 7. Legal and practical considerations: The U.S. electoral system is set up for one presidential candidate per party. Having two nominees would create significant legal and logistical issues. Given these factors, it is extremely unlikely that both Tim Scott and Chris Christie will be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The probability is very close to zero.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Francis Suarez becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. National recognition: Suarez has limited national recognition compared to other potential Republican candidates. Competition: There are several high-profile Republicans who are either already running or considering running for the nomination. These include Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others who have more national recognition and experience in federal politics. 4. question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face significant primary challenges, let alone a situation that leads to a brokered convention. 2. Party unity: The Democratic Party has generally shown strong support for Biden's presidency, and there are no major factions or candidates openly challenging his leadership. 3. Lack of prominent challengers: As of now, there are no high-profile Democrats who have announced a primary challenge against Biden. The few candidates who have declared their intention to run have very little name recognition or party support. 4. Biden's age and health: While Biden's age (he will be 81 in 2024) and occasional gaffes have raised some concerns, these factors alone are unlikely to lead to a brokered convention unless there's a significant health event. 5. Historical precedent: Brokered conventions are extremely rare in modern American politics. The last time Democrats had a truly brokered convention was in 1952. Since then, the primary process has become more streamlined and front-loaded, making brokered conventions even less likely. 6. Current political climate: While Biden's approval ratings have fluctuated, there isn't a groundswell of opposition within the Democratic Party that would suggest a serious challenge to his nomination. 7. Time until the convention: There is still over a year until the Democratic National Convention. While this leaves time for unexpected events, it also gives the party ample opportunity to rally behind Biden or an alternative candidate if necessary. Given these factors, the likelihood of a brokered Democratic convention in 2024 is very low. For a brokered convention to occur, there would need to be a perfect storm of events: Biden deciding not to run (or being unable to run) at the last minute, multiple strong candidates entering the race late, and a highly divided electorate among Democratic primary voters. While not impossible, this scenario is highly improbable.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Francis Suarez be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election (b) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Francis Suarez is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not by who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. (2) The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If both conditions are not met, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both events occurring, we need to consider each event separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. Francis Suarez being the Republican nominee: Francis Suarez is currently the Mayor of Miami and has announced his bid for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination. However, he is considered a long-shot candidate for several reasons: - He has low national name recognition compared to other candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley. - He lacks significant fundraising and national political infrastructure. - His moderate positions on some issues may not appeal to the Republican base. - Current polling shows him with very low support among Republican voters. Given these factors, the probability of Suarez becoming the Republican nominee is extremely low, likely less than 1%. 2. Democrats having a brokered convention: A brokered convention occurs when no candidate secures a majority of delegates in the first round of voting. For the Democrats in 2024, this scenario is also highly unlikely because: - Incumbent President Joe Biden is expected to run for re-election. - Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face serious primary challenges. - The Democratic Party typically rallies around incumbents to present a united front. - There are currently no high-profile Democrats challenging Biden for the nomination. The probability of a Democratic brokered convention is also very low, perhaps around 2-3%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these already low probabilities, which results in an extremely small number. Even if we generously estimate each event at 1% (which is likely an overestimate), the combined probability would be 0.01 * 0.01 = 0.0001 or 0.01%. Given the extreme unlikelihood of both these events occurring simultaneously, I would assign a very low probability to this scenario.

question.title: Will the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee be a Woman?
question.body:
Will resolve “yes” if/when the Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

Will resolve “no” if/when the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee being a woman, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current frontrunner: As of now, Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for 2024. He has not indicated any intention to step down, and incumbents typically have a strong advantage in securing their party's nomination. 2. Potential female candidates: While there are several prominent female Democrats who could potentially run, such as Vice President Kamala Harris, Senator Elizabeth Warren, or Governor Gretchen Whitmer, none have announced intentions to challenge Biden for the nomination. 3. Historical context: The Democratic Party has never nominated a woman for president in its history, with Hillary Clinton in 2016 being the closest. This suggests a historical bias, though it's weakening over time. 4. Time frame: The question's resolution date is set for August 6, 2024, which aligns with the typical timeframe for the Democratic National Convention. This gives little time for unexpected changes in the political landscape. 5. Biden's age and health: At 81 years old (in 2024), Biden's age could be a factor. If he were to step down or face health issues, it could open the door for other candidates, potentially including women. 6. Party unity: The Democratic Party is likely to prioritize unity and avoiding a contentious primary battle that could weaken their position against the Republican nominee. Given these factors, the probability of a woman being the Democratic nominee in 2024 is quite low. Biden's incumbency and the lack of any serious female challengers at this point make it highly unlikely. However, there's always a small chance of unexpected events occurring, such as Biden deciding not to run or facing unforeseen circumstances that force him to step aside.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, voleyball and water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: In previous Olympics, it's been common for certain countries to dominate in multiple team sports. For example, the United States has been strong in both basketball disciplines, while the Netherlands has excelled in field hockey. 2. Number of sports: With eight different team sports, the chances of one country winning multiple golds increases. 3. Varying strengths of different countries: Some nations are powerhouses in specific sports but not others. For instance, the US is strong in basketball, while Australia is traditionally strong in water polo. 4. Recent performances: Looking at recent World Championships and international tournaments can give us an idea of which countries are currently strong in each sport. 5. Depth of competition: Some sports have a wider pool of competitive nations than others, which affects the likelihood of repeat winners. 6. Olympic-specific factors: Home advantage, team preparation, and the unique pressure of the Olympics can sometimes lead to unexpected results. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that one nation will win more than one women's team sport. The United States, in particular, has a good chance of winning both 3x3 and 5x5 basketball. Other countries like Australia, the Netherlands, or China also have strong teams in multiple sports. While it's certainly possible for eight different nations to win the eight gold medals, the historical precedent and the current strength of certain countries in multiple disciplines make it more likely that at least one nation will win multiple golds.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee will be a Woman (b) The same nation will win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?

For example: 1. The United States often performs well in basketball (both 5x5 and 3x3) and volleyball. 2. The Netherlands is strong in both field hockey and football. 3. Australia has shown strength in water polo and rugby sevens. Given the historical performance and the fact that there are eight different team sports, it's quite likely that at least one nation will win more than one gold medal in women's team sports. Probability for (b): Approximately 0.8 or 80%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.1 * 0.8 = 0.08 or 8%. This combined probability is quite low, primarily due to the low likelihood of a female Democratic presidential nominee in 2024.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

Political landscape: As of now (July 2024), we don't have information about any major upcoming events that could dramatically shift Harris's odds in the next week. 5. Given these factors, I believe there's a modest chance of Harris's odds increasing, but it's more likely they will remain stable or decrease slightly due to the model's tendency towards stability in short time frames. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: There's evident dissatisfaction among some Democrats regarding the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. This suggests there's motivation for opposition. 2. Time frame: The market closes on July 21st, giving approximately two weeks for this letter to materialize and gather signatures. This is a relatively short period, which could make it challenging to organize and collect signatures. 3. Number of signatures required: The threshold of 20 signatures is significant but not overwhelmingly high, considering there are hundreds of Democratic members in the House and Senate combined. 4. Existing efforts: Rep. Jared Huffman has already drafted a letter and is circulating it, indicating that the process has already begun. 5. Political risk: Signing such a letter could be seen as opposing the party leadership, which some members might be hesitant to do openly. 6. Urgency of the issue: The attempted assassination of former President Trump adds a layer of complexity to the political landscape, which might either accelerate or slow down this effort. 7. Precedent: Democrats have shown willingness to publicly disagree with party leadership on other issues in the past. Given these factors, I believe there's a moderate to high chance of this occurring. The existing draft and circulation of the letter, combined with the reported discontent among 'dozens' of House Democrats, suggests that reaching 20 signatures is quite feasible. However, the short timeframe and potential political risks provide some counterbalance.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the likelihood of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face significant challenges within their own party. 2. Current political landscape: As of now, there are no major challengers to Biden within the Democratic Party. While there have been some concerns about his age and approval ratings, the party seems largely united behind him. 3. Time frame: The question was created on July 8, 2024, which is very close to the convention date (typically held in July or August). By this time, the primary process would be essentially over, and the nominee would usually be clear. 4. Party unity: The Democratic Party has shown a tendency to unite behind their candidate to present a strong front against the Republican opposition. They are likely to want to avoid the appearance of disunity that a brokered convention might suggest. 5. Historical precedent: Brokered conventions are extremely rare in modern American politics. The last time Democrats had a truly brokered convention was in 1952. 6. Delegate allocation rules: The Democratic Party's proportional allocation of delegates makes it more likely for a clear winner to emerge before the convention. 7. Party leadership influence: Party leaders and superdelegates would likely work behind the scenes to ensure a smooth nomination process, avoiding a brokered convention scenario. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that the Democrats will have a brokered convention in 2024. The probability of this occurring is very low, barring any unforeseen major events or scandals that could dramatically shake up the race at the last minute.

The Politico article suggests that 'dozens' of House Democrats are organizing to speak out against the early nomination plan. Rep. question.title: Will a member of the Trump family be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024?
question.body:
Resolves **Yes** if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024:

 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a Trump family member becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Donald Trump's influence: Despite his controversial presidency and two impeachments, Donald Trump remains a significant figure in the Republican Party. He has a strong base of supporters and continues to wield considerable influence within the party. 2. Donald Trump's intentions: Trump has repeatedly hinted at running again in 2024. As of now, he is the most likely Trump family member to seek the nomination. 3. Other Trump family members: While Donald Trump Jr. and Ivanka Trump have some political presence, they lack the experience and broad support base of their father. The other family members listed have even less political experience or expressed interest in running. 4. However, Trump's base remains strong enough to make him a formidable candidate. 5. Given these factors, Donald Trump appears to be the most likely Trump family member to secure the nomination, with other family members having a much lower chance. While there are significant obstacles and uncertainties, Trump's enduring popularity within the Republican Party and his apparent intention to run make it a strong possibility.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Public opinion polls: The prompt mentions that public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, while other hypothetical Democratic candidates poll ahead or within the margin of error against Trump. This suggests that Biden is generally perceived as a weaker candidate compared to a generic Democrat. 2. Manifold respondents vs. general public: The question asks if Manifold respondents are representative of the general public. Without specific data on Manifold's user base, we can't be certain, but we should assume that they might have some differences from the general public, possibly skewing towards more politically engaged or informed individuals. 3. The 3% threshold: The question requires Trump to gain at least 3% more votes when facing Biden compared to a generic Democrat. This is a significant difference, considering that elections are often decided by smaller margins. 4. Timing: The polls close on July 6, 2024, which is relatively close to the actual election. By this time, voters will likely have more concrete opinions about the candidates. 5. Potential for change: There's still time for public opinion to shift, but the consistent trend in public polls suggests a persistent weakness for Biden compared to other Democrats. 6. Manifold's potential bias: As a prediction market platform, Manifold users might be more attuned to polling data and general election trends, which could influence their voting in these polls to align more closely with broader public opinion. Given these factors, it seems likely that Trump would perform better against Biden than against a generic Democrat in the Manifold polls. The consistent trend in public polls showing Biden as a weaker candidate is a strong indicator. Even if Manifold respondents differ somewhat from the general public, they are likely aware of these trends and may vote accordingly. However, the 3% threshold is substantial, and there's always a possibility that Manifold users might not reflect the full extent of this difference. Still, given the strong and consistent trend in public polling, I believe it's more likely than not that this threshold will be met.

question.body:
This question resolves **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes:
   - Donald Trump
   - Donald Trump Jr.
   - Eric Trump
   - Ivanka Trump
   - Tiffany Trump
   - Melania Trump
   - Barron Trump

2. In two Manifold polls closing on July 6, the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in a poll with Joe Biden on the ballot exceeds the percentage in a poll with a generic Democrat by 3% or more. The formula used is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The market resolves YES if the result from poll 1 minus the result from poll 2 is >= 0.03. Otherwise, it resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine them. 1. A Trump family member as the Republican nominee: Currently, Donald Trump is the frontrunner for the Republican nomination. He has a significant lead in polls and maintains a strong base of support within the party. While there are other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley, Trump's dominance makes him the most likely nominee. The probability of another Trump family member being nominated is extremely low. I'd estimate the probability of a Trump family member (most likely Donald Trump himself) being the nominee at around 80%. 2. Trump gaining at least 3% against Biden compared to a generic Democrat: This condition is more challenging to predict. Historically, named candidates often perform differently than generic party candidates in polls. Biden, as a known quantity, might perform better or worse than a generic Democrat depending on various factors like his approval ratings, the state of the economy, and current events. Trump has a polarizing effect, which could potentially lead to a difference in his performance against Biden versus a generic Democrat. However, a 3% difference is significant. Given that both Trump and Biden are well-known figures, the difference might not be as large as 3%. Additionally, this condition relies on specific Manifold polls, which adds another layer of uncertainty. The timing of these polls (July 6) could be influenced by campaign events, debates, or other factors that are difficult to predict this far in advance. Considering these factors, I'd estimate the probability of Trump gaining at least 3% against Biden compared to a generic Democrat in these specific polls at around 40%. To resolve YES, both conditions must be met. We can approximate the overall probability by multiplying the probabilities of each condition: 0.80 * 0.40 = 0.32 or 32%. This calculation assumes independence between the two events, which may not be entirely accurate, but it provides a reasonable estimate.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and capacity of President Biden: While there have been concerns about Biden's age and occasional gaffes, there's no concrete evidence of severe cognitive decline or incapacitation that would warrant invoking the 25th Amendment. 2. Political landscape: The invocation of the 25th Amendment, Section 4, is an extremely rare and serious action. It would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree, which is unlikely in the current political climate where Democrats control the executive branch. 3. Time frame: The question asks about this happening before August 2024, which is a relatively short time frame (less than a month from the creation date of this question). 4. Historical precedent: The 25th Amendment, Section 4 has never been invoked in U.S. history, highlighting its extraordinary nature. 5. Recent context: While a GOP lawmaker has asked Attorney General Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, this is likely a political move rather than a reflection of Biden's actual capacity. The Attorney General does not have the power to invoke the 25th Amendment independently. 6. Biden administration's stance: There's no indication from within the administration that such a drastic measure is being considered or that Biden's cabinet has any concerns about his ability to discharge his duties. 7. Upcoming election: With the 2024 presidential election approaching, it's highly unlikely that the Democratic party would risk such a controversial and potentially damaging move. Given these factors, the probability of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is extremely low. While it's not impossible, it would require a sudden and severe decline in Biden's health or capacity, coupled with a dramatic shift in the political landscape.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling and forecasts: As of July 2023, Biden and Trump are the frontrunners for their respective parties, but the election is still over a year away. Polls and forecasts can change significantly in that time. 2. Historical precedent: Incumbent presidents often have an advantage in re-election bids, which could favor Biden. 3. Economic factors: The state of the economy in July 2024 will likely play a significant role in voter sentiment. 4. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: They are known for their data-driven approach and have been relatively accurate in past elections. 5. Potential unforeseen events: Major national or international events could significantly impact public opinion before July 2024. 6. Primary outcomes: While Biden and Trump are currently favored, there's still a possibility that neither ends up as their party's nominee. 7. FiveThirtyEight's historical trends: They tend to be cautious in their predictions early on and adjust as more data becomes available closer to the election. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that Biden will be favored in FiveThirtyEight's forecast on July 19, 2024. The incumbent advantage, combined with FiveThirtyEight's typically cautious approach, suggests they may lean slightly towards Biden. However, the margin is likely to be narrow given the potential volatility of the next year in politics. It's important to note that this is a projection far into the future, and many unforeseen events could dramatically shift the landscape. The certainty of this prediction is relatively low due to the time frame involved.

question.title: Will Joe Biden still be president by the end of July?
question.body: This market will resolve yes if at 11:59 pm on July 31st 2024 if Joe Biden is still officially president of the United States.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden still being president by the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. With such a short timeframe, it's highly unlikely to occur and conclude before July 31. c) Health issues or death: While Biden is of advanced age, there's no public information suggesting imminent health concerns that would force him to leave office. d) 25th Amendment: Invocation of this amendment to remove the president is extremely rare and usually temporary. 5. Political climate: While political tensions can be high, especially in an election year, there are no signs of an imminent threat to Biden's presidency that would cause him to leave office in the next two weeks. 6. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a U.S. president to leave office unexpectedly, especially so close to the end of their term. Given these factors, it is highly likely that Joe Biden will still be president by the end of July 2024. The only significant risks would be unforeseen health issues or extremely unlikely political events, but the probability of these occurring within such a short timeframe is very low.
